In the 20th century, in the late 1940s, the Yamashita standard derived from the incorporation into the U.S. Code of the developments of the legal doctrine of command responsibility presented in the Nuremberg trials (1945–1946). Abiding by that legal precedent, the U.S. Supreme Court allowed the U.S. prosecution of the war crimes case against Imperial Japanese Army General Tomoyuki Yamashita for the atrocities committed by his soldiers in the Philippine Islands, in the Pacific Theatre (1941–1945) of the Second World War. The International Military Tribunal for the Far East charged, tried, and judged Gen. Yamashita for "unlawfully disregarding, and failing to discharge, his duty as a commander to control the acts of members of his command, by permitting them to commit war crimes".
In the 20th century, in the early 1970s, the Medina standard expanded the U.S. Code to include the criminal liability of American military officers for the war crimes committed by their subordinates, as are the war-criminal military officers of an enemy power. The Medina standard was established in the court martial of U.S. Army Captain Ernest Medina in 1971 for not exercising his command authority as a company commander, by not acting to halt the My Lai massacre (16 March 1968) committed by his soldiers during the Vietnam War (1955–1975).
story:
In a small town, Captain Roberts was in charge of a local police unit known for its strict discipline. One day, during a routine patrol, some of his junior officers, under the influence of a corrupt official, violated the rights of a group of peaceful protesters, leading to a violent clash.

Despite knowing about the misconduct, Captain Roberts chose to turn a blind eye and did not take any action to stop the abuse. As a result, several individuals were severely injured, and the incident sparked outrage in the community.

When the matter was brought to court, it was revealed that Captain Roberts had failed in his duty to control the actions of his subordinates, thereby violating the legal concept of command responsibility. He was held accountable for the wrongful acts of his officers under his command.

Through this story, we understand that leaders in positions of authority, whether military or civilian, have a legal obligation to prevent and punish any violations of human rights committed by those under their command, under the doctrine of command responsibility.

definition: In law, a commanding precedent is a precedent whose facts are "on all fours" with the case at hand. In other words, it almost exactly tracks it, sharing near-identical facts and issues. A commanding precedent is also referred to as a "Goose" case in Louisiana; "Spotted Horse" or "Spotted Dog" cases in Alabama; "Cow" case in Kansas; and "White Horse" or "White Pony" cases in Texas. A legal rule can be "clearly established" without commanding precedent existing. For example, in the United States, a governmental official is generally protected by qualified immunity if his acts were objectively legally reasonable, but such protection may not apply if, in light of pre-existing law, the unlawfulness of his conduct would have been apparent to a reasonably competent official, even if no commanding precedent applicable to his specific behavior existed.
story:
In the small town of Oakwood, a peculiar case unfolded that would come to be known as the "White Pony" case. It all started when two neighbors, Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith, got into a heated dispute over the ownership of a beautiful white pony named Snowflake.

Mr. Johnson claimed that Snowflake had wandered onto his property and that he had taken care of her for months, making her his own. On the other hand, Mr. Smith argued that Snowflake had escaped from his pasture temporarily and that he was the rightful owner.

As the case went to court, the judge was faced with a dilemma. There was no clear legal precedent in their state regarding such a unique situation involving animal ownership. However, the judge remembered a similar case from a neighboring state that was often referred to as the "White Horse" case. The facts and legal issues in that case were strikingly similar to the current dispute over Snowflake.

Relying on the principles established in the "White Horse" case, the judge ruled in favor of Mr. Smith, citing the commanding precedent that guided his decision. This decision not only settled the dispute between the neighbors but also set a new legal precedent in Oakwood for future cases involving animal ownership rights.

definition: Common employment was an historical defence in English tort law that said workers implicitly undertook the risks of being injured by their co-workers, with whom they were in "common employment". The US labor law terminology was the "fellow servant rule".
story:
Once upon a time, in a bustling factory, there were two workers, Sarah and James. They worked side by side on the noisy assembly line, diligently putting together widgets for hours on end.

One fateful day, as the factory floor hummed with activity, James accidentally dropped a heavy toolbox from a high shelf. The toolbox landed with a loud crash, narrowly missing Sarah but causing her to trip and injure her wrist. Sarah was in pain and couldn't work for weeks, leading to financial strain.

When Sarah sought legal recourse for her injury, the concept of common employment came into play. The factory’s legal team argued that because Sarah and James were both employees working for the same employer, they were considered to be in “common employment”. As such, Sarah had implicitly accepted the risks associated with working alongside her fellow employees, including the possibility of accidents caused by their actions.

Despite Sarah's objections about James’ negligence, the common employment doctrine shielded the factory from liability for her injury. It was a stark reminder that in the world of tort law, the fellow servant rule could sometimes leave injured workers without the compensation they sought, highlighting the importance of workplace safety and accountability.

definition: Comparative negligence, called non-absolute contributory negligence outside the United States, is a partial legal defense that reduces the amount of damages that a plaintiff can recover in a negligence-based claim, based upon the degree to which the plaintiff's own negligence contributed to cause the injury. When the defense is asserted, the factfinder, usually a jury, must decide the degree to which the plaintiff's negligence and the combined negligence of all other relevant actors all contributed to cause the plaintiff's damages. It is a modification of the doctrine of contributory negligence that disallows any recovery by a plaintiff whose negligence contributed even minimally to causing the damages.
story:
In a bustling city, Sarah was walking briskly down the crowded sidewalk on her way to work. Lost in thought about the day ahead, she failed to notice the "wet floor" sign outside a cafe and slipped on a spilled drink, falling hard to the ground. As a result, Sarah sustained injuries to her wrist and ankle, requiring medical treatment and causing her to miss work for a week.

Sarah decided to take legal action against the cafe, claiming they were negligent in not cleaning up the spill promptly. However, during the trial, it came to light that Sarah had been texting on her phone while walking and may have avoided the accident if she had been more attentive.

The jury determined that while the cafe was partly at fault for not addressing the spill in a timely manner, Sarah's own negligence in failing to pay attention to her surroundings also contributed to the accident. They found that Sarah's own negligence was 30% responsible for the incident, reducing the damages she could recover from the cafe accordingly.

This case illustrated the legal concept of comparative negligence, where the plaintiff's damages are reduced based on the degree to which their own actions contributed to the harm suffered. In this scenario, both parties shared responsibility for the accident, leading to a fair apportionment of damages.

definition: A condemned property or a condemned building is a property or building that local (usually municipal) authorities have closed, seized, or placed restrictions on for various reasons, including public safety and public health, in accordance with local ordinance.
story:
In the heart of a bustling city, there stood an old apartment building that had seen better days. Its faded facade told stories of years gone by, but now, it harbored a darker secret. The city officials deemed it a condemned property, citing multiple safety code violations and hazardous living conditions.

Within the building, Mrs. Thompson, an elderly widow, had called it home for over three decades. She cherished the memories within those walls, but the creaking floors and leaky pipes told a different tale. One fateful day, a section of the building's roof caved in, narrowly missing Mrs. Thompson.

Terrified and shaken, she contacted the authorities, who promptly condemned the building, declaring it unfit for human habitation. Mrs. Thompson was forced to evacuate, her beloved home now off-limits due to the risks it posed.

As the building stood empty, its windows boarded up, it served as a stark reminder of the legal concept of condemned property. The city took action to protect its residents, ensuring that no one would be harmed by the deteriorating structure. Mrs. Thompson found a new place to call home, but the echoes of her old apartment lingered, a cautionary tale of the consequences of neglecting property safety regulations.

definition:
Consideration is a concept of English common law and is a necessity for simple contracts but not for special contracts (contracts by deed). The concept has been adopted by other common law jurisdictions. It is commonly referred to as one of the six or seven elements of a contract.
The court in Currie v Misa declared consideration to be a "Right,  Interest,  Profit,  Benefit, or Forbearance,  Detriment,  Loss,  Responsibility". Thus, consideration is a promise of something of value given by a promissor in exchange for something of value given by a promisee; and typically the thing of value is goods, money, or an act. Forbearance to act, such as an adult promising to refrain from smoking, is enforceable only if one is thereby surrendering a legal right.
Consideration may be thought of as the concept of value offered and accepted by people or organisations entering into contracts. Anything of value promised by one party to the other when making a contract can be treated as "consideration": for example, if A contracts to buy a car from B for $5,000, A's consideration is the promise of $5,000, and B's consideration is the promise of the car.
Additionally, if A signs a contract with B such that A will paint B's house for $500, A's consideration is the service of painting B's house, and B's consideration is $500 paid to A. Further if A signs a contract with B such that A will not repaint his own house in any other colour than white, and B will pay A $500 per year to keep this deal up, there is also a consideration. Although A did not promise to affirmatively do anything, A did promise not to do something that he was allowed to do, and so A did pass consideration. A's consideration to B is the forbearance in painting his own house in a colour other than white, and B's consideration to A is $500 per year. Conversely, if A signs a contract to buy a car from B for $0, B's consideration is still the car, but A is giving no consideration, and so there is no valid contract. However, if B still gives the title to the car to A, then B cannot take the car back, since, while it may not be a valid contract, it is a valid gift.
story:
Once upon a time, there was a struggling artist named Lily who dreamt of owning her own gallery one day. One day, a wealthy collector named Mr. Johnson approached Lily with a proposition. He offered to buy one of her prized paintings for $10,000 but requested that she promise not to sell any more copies of that painting in the future.

In this scenario, Lily's promise to refrain from selling additional copies of the painting serves as her consideration to Mr. Johnson. In exchange for her promise, Mr. Johnson's consideration is the $10,000 payment for the painting.

As Lily hesitated, Mr. Johnson sweetened the deal by offering to display her artwork prominently in his personal collection and to introduce her to other art enthusiasts. Lily saw the opportunity to gain exposure and build her reputation, so she agreed to the deal.

This exchange of promises and benefits between Lily and Mr. Johnson exemplifies the legal concept of consideration in a contract. Both parties gave something of value – the painting, the promise not to replicate it, and the monetary payment – to create a valid and enforceable agreement.

And so, Lily's art found a new home in Mr. Johnson's collection, marking the beginning of her journey towards achieving her dream of owning a gallery, all thanks to the fundamental principle of consideration in contract law.

definition:
A convention, also known as a constitutional convention, is an uncodified tradition that is followed by the institutions of a state. In some states, notably those Commonwealth states that follow the Westminster system and whose political systems derive from British constitutional law, most government functions are guided by constitutional convention rather than by a formal written constitution. In these states, actual distribution of power may be markedly different from those the formal constitutional documents describe. In particular, the formal constitution often confers wide discretionary powers on the head of state that, in practice, are used only on the advice of the head of government, and in some cases not at all.
Some constitutional conventions operate separately from or alongside written constitutions, such as in Canada since the country was formed with the enactment of the Constitution Act, 1867. In others, notably the United Kingdom, which lack a single overarching constitutional document, unwritten conventions are still of vital importance in understanding how the state functions. In most states, however, many old conventions have been replaced or superseded by laws (called codification).
Historical entities often had strong emphasis on constitutional convention. For example the constitution of the Roman Republic was codified comparatively late in its development and relied for its functioning on traditions and a shared moral code called mos maiorum. In the Holy Roman Empire such important issues as who could elect the emperor were entirely uncodified before the Golden Bull of 1356 and remained subject to a certain degree of interpretation well afterwards.
story:
In the small fictional country of Rivertown, there was a long-standing tradition known as the Harvest Festival, where the Mayor would officially open the ceremony by planting the first seed in the communal garden. This tradition dated back centuries, even before the country had a formal written constitution.

Over time, the Harvest Festival became ingrained in the fabric of Rivertown's governance, with the Mayor's participation symbolizing unity and prosperity for the community. While there was no law mandating the Mayor's involvement in the festival, it had become an unwritten rule that all Mayors followed without question.

One year, a newly elected Mayor, Mayor Lee, questioned the necessity of participating in the Harvest Festival. He argued that as the head of the town, he should focus on more pressing issues than planting a seed in the garden.

The townspeople were taken aback by Mayor Lee's refusal to partake in the tradition. They believed that the Harvest Festival and the Mayor's symbolic role were essential for maintaining harmony and tradition in Rivertown. Without a formal law requiring the Mayor's participation, the townspeople had to rely on the uncodified tradition of the Harvest Festival to ensure continuity and unity in their community.

In the end, Mayor Lee conceded to tradition, recognizing the importance of upholding the constitutional convention that had guided Rivertown for generations. The Harvest Festival continued to be a cherished annual event, reinforcing the power of unwritten conventions in shaping the governance of their beloved town.

doctrine: Constitutional conventions of the United Kingdom
definition: The United Kingdom has an uncodified constitution. The constitution consists of legislation, common law, Crown prerogative and constitutional conventions. Conventions may be written or unwritten. They are principles of behaviour which are not legally enforceable, but form part of the constitution by being enforced on a political, professional or personal level. Written conventions can be found in the Ministerial Code, Cabinet Manual, Guide to Judicial Conduct, Erskine May and even legislation. Unwritten conventions exist by virtue of long-practice or may be referenced in other documents such as the Lascelles Principles.
story:
Once upon a time in the bustling city of London, there was a newly elected Prime Minister named Emily. Excited but slightly nervous, she quickly found herself facing a dilemma in the form of a crucial decision regarding national security. Seeking advice, she turned to her trusted Cabinet members and the Ministerial Code for guidance.

In a heated Cabinet meeting, each member shared their perspectives, rooted in the unwritten constitutional convention that the Prime Minister should consult with her Cabinet before making significant decisions. Despite differing opinions, the discussion was respectful and reflective of the importance of collective responsibility in governance.

As the meeting concluded, Emily felt reassured by the adherence to this convention, ensuring transparency and accountability in her decision-making process. She understood that while not legally binding, constitutional conventions like consulting with Cabinet members were vital components of the UK's governance framework, built on mutual respect and collaboration.

Ultimately, Emily made her decision with the support of her Cabinet, upholding the traditions and practices that have guided UK governance for centuries, even in the absence of a codified constitution. And so, the story of Emily's reliance on constitutional conventions to navigate the complexities of leadership became a testament to the enduring principles that underpin the UK's constitutional framework.

doctrine: Contra principia negantem non est disputandum
definition: Contra principia negantem non est disputandum (Latin, alternatively Contra principia negantem disputari non potest and Contra principia negantem disputari nequit; literally, "Against one who denies the principles, there can be no debate") is a principle of logic and law: in order to debate reasonably about a disagreement, there must be agreement about the principles or facts by which to judge the arguments.
story:
In a small town nestled between rolling hills, there lived two neighbors, Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith, who couldn't seem to agree on anything. From property boundaries to community projects, their differing opinions led to constant disputes that disrupted the peace of the neighborhood.

One day, their argument escalated when Mr. Johnson claimed that a portion of his fence was encroaching on Mr. Smith's land. Mr. Smith vehemently denied the accusation, leading to a heated confrontation that drew the attention of other residents.

Frustrated by the ongoing conflict, the town mayor decided to intervene and organize a community meeting to resolve the dispute. As the townspeople gathered in the community hall, the mayor emphasized the importance of abiding by the legal principle of 'Contra principia negantem non est disputandum'.

He explained that in order to reach a fair and just resolution, both parties must first agree on the basic facts and principles concerning property boundaries and land ownership. Without this common ground, any debate or discussion would be futile and only lead to further discord.

Realizing the wisdom in the mayor's words, Mr. Johnson and Mr. Smith reluctantly agreed to consult a surveyor to determine the exact property lines. Once the survey results were presented, it became clear that Mr. Johnson's fence was indeed encroaching on Mr. Smith's land.

With the undeniable evidence before them, the neighbors finally found common ground and were able to settle their dispute amicably, illustrating the importance of agreeing on principles before engaging in debate.

definition: Contra proferentem (Latin: "against [the] offeror"), also known as "interpretation against the draftsman", is a doctrine of contractual interpretation providing that, where a promise, agreement or term is ambiguous, the preferred meaning should be the one that works against the interests of the party who provided the wording.
story:
Amy, a recent college graduate, eagerly signed a contract with a tech company for her first job. In her excitement, she didn't pay much attention to the fine print. However, on her first day at work, she was shocked to discover that the job responsibilities were vastly different from what she had initially understood.

When Amy confronted her employer about this discrepancy, they pointed to a specific clause in the contract that described her duties vaguely. Feeling deceived, Amy sought legal advice. Her attorney explained the legal concept of 'Contra proferentem' to her - emphasizing that when a provision in a contract is unclear, the interpretation should be made against the interests of the party who drafted the contract.

Armed with this knowledge, Amy confronted her employer again, citing the doctrine of 'Contra proferentem' to argue that the ambiguous clause should be interpreted in her favor. Faced with the threat of a legal dispute, the tech company reconsidered and agreed to adjust her job responsibilities to align with what was initially promised to her.

In the end, Amy learned the importance of paying attention to contractual details and how legal principles like 'Contra proferentem' could protect individuals from potential misunderstandings and exploitation.

definition:
In some common law jurisdictions, contributory negligence is a defense to a tort claim based on negligence. If it is available, the defense completely bars plaintiffs from any recovery if they contribute to their own injury through their own negligence. 
Because the contributory negligence doctrine can lead to harsh results, many common law jurisdictions have abolished it in favor of a "comparative fault" or "comparative negligence" approach. A comparative negligence approach reduces the plaintiff's damages award by the percentage of fault the fact-finder assigns to the plaintiff for their own injury. For example, if a jury thinks the plaintiff is 30% at fault, the plaintiff's damages award will be reduced by 30%.
story:
In downtown Rivertown, Emily hurriedly crossed the street while texting on her phone, oblivious to the oncoming traffic. At the same time, Mark, speeding slightly over the limit, approached the intersection. In a split second, their worlds collided, resulting in a minor collision that left both shaken but thankfully uninjured.

As the dust settled, Emily was quick to blame Mark for the accident, claiming he was driving recklessly and should be solely responsible for the damages to her car. However, upon further investigation, it became evident that Emily had crossed the street against the traffic signal and failed to look both ways before stepping onto the road.

In court, the judge considered the principle of contributory negligence. Despite Mark's speeding, Emily's actions also contributed to the accident. Under the doctrine of contributory negligence, since Emily was found to be 40% at fault for the collision due to her distracted jaywalking, she was not entitled to any compensation for her car damages. The judge highlighted that both parties had a responsibility to exercise reasonable care.

This case highlighted the importance of being vigilant and responsible to avoid accidents, as contributory negligence can play a significant role in determining legal liability.

definition: The corporate opportunity doctrine is the legal principle providing that directors, officers, and controlling shareholders of a corporation must not take for themselves any business opportunity that could benefit the corporation.  The corporate opportunity doctrine is one application of the fiduciary duty of loyalty.
story:
Once, there was a successful software company called TechGen that was looking to expand its services to include artificial intelligence programs. The CEO, Sarah, was brainstorming ideas at a company retreat when she overheard a conversation between two employees discussing a promising AI startup, ByteMind, which was looking for investors.

Excited by the opportunity, Sarah quickly did some research and realized that ByteMind's technology could greatly benefit TechGen's future projects. However, instead of informing the board and exploring a potential partnership for TechGen, Sarah decided to secretly invest her personal funds in ByteMind, without disclosing her involvement to anyone at TechGen.

As ByteMind's technology flourished, TechGen missed out on a valuable opportunity to enhance its own AI capabilities. When the board eventually found out about Sarah's investment in ByteMind, they were furious. Sarah had violated the corporate opportunity doctrine by putting her own interests above those of the company - a breach of her fiduciary duty of loyalty as CEO.

The board took legal action against Sarah, ultimately leading to her removal as CEO for failing to act in the best interests of TechGen. The story of TechGen serves as a cautionary tale about the importance of directors and officers avoiding conflicts of interest and always prioritizing the interests of the corporation over personal gain.

definition: The correlative rights doctrine is a legal doctrine limiting the rights of landowners to a common source of groundwater (such as an aquifer) to a reasonable share, typically based on the amount of land owned by each on the surface above.  This doctrine is also applied to oil and gas in some U.S. states.
story:
In a small town called Oakwood, the Smith and Brown families lived on neighboring farms. One day, the town discovered a rich underground aquifer beneath both their properties, providing a vital water source for the entire community. The families quickly began using the groundwater to irrigate their crops and supply their homes.

However, conflicts soon arose as the Smiths began pumping water excessively, causing the aquifer's water level to drop significantly. The Browns noticed their own well drying up as a result, leading to tensions between the two families.

Seeking a resolution, the town council invoked the correlative rights doctrine, explaining that all landowners sharing the aquifer must use its water responsibly and in a manner that ensures each party receives a fair share. The doctrine required the Smiths and Browns to work together to monitor their water usage and prevent over-extraction to protect the common groundwater source for all.

Through cooperation and communication, the families learned to balance their water usage, understanding that their correlative rights to the aquifer required them to share the resource equitably based on the amount of land they owned above it. The application of the correlative rights doctrine helped the families resolve their dispute and preserve the precious groundwater for the community's benefit.

definition:
The crumbling skull rule is a well-established legal doctrine used in some tort law systems.  It holds that where a plaintiff had a condition or injury that predates the tort and would have naturally deteriorated or worsened over time (e.g. a crumbling skull), the defendant is not responsible to the degree that the condition or injury would have naturally worsened over time.  A defendant is only liable for the degree the injury was worsened or the hastening or acceleration of the damage caused by the tort.  The crumbling skull rule should not be confused with the related thin skull rule.
The concept is sometimes applied without specific reference to the crumbling skull rule, instead being expressed as a non-absolute application of the thin skull rule.
story:
Samantha, a dedicated nurse, was involved in a car accident caused by a careless driver running a red light. As a result, Samantha suffered a neck injury that exacerbated her pre-existing degenerative disc disease. Her doctors determined that her condition was like a "crumbling skull," meaning it was an injury that would have worsened over time even without the accident.

In court, the defendant argued that they should not be held fully responsible for Samantha's entire neck injury because of the pre-existing condition. The judge considered the crumbling skull rule and explained that the defendant was only accountable for the extent to which the accident accelerated or worsened Samantha's condition beyond what would have naturally occurred.

After careful evaluation, the judge ruled in favor of Samantha, acknowledging that while her condition would have deteriorated over time, the accident significantly hastened the progression and severity of her neck injury. The defendant was held liable for the exacerbated damage caused by the accident, providing Samantha with compensation for her medical expenses and pain and suffering.

Through Samantha's story, the crumbling skull rule became clear - a defendant in a tort case is only responsible for the additional harm caused by their actions, not for the entirety of a pre-existing condition that would have naturally worsened over time.

definition: The dangerous proximity doctrine is an American standard for distinguishing between preparation and attempt in a criminal case.: 683  Under this standard, evidence that preparatory acts are an actual attempt is considered to be stronger if the offense is more probable and more grave or serious; if the defendant is nearer to completing the intended crime; and if the defendant's acts are likely to lead to the commission of the crime.: 683  However, the standard is not a clear bright line.

Demise of the Crown is the legal term in the United Kingdom and the other Commonwealth realms for the transfer of the Crown upon the death or abdication of the monarch. The Crown transfers automatically to the monarch's heir. The concept evolved in the kingdom of England, and was continued in Great Britain and then the United Kingdom. The concept also became part of the constitutions of the British colonies, and was continued in the constitutions of the Commonwealth realms, until modified within those realms.
Originally, the demise of the Crown in England had significant legal effects: individuals who had been appointed to office by the deceased monarch lost their positions; if Parliament was sitting, it automatically dissolved; and actions in the royal courts automatically discontinued and had to be re-started. Almost all of these legal effects have been abolished by statutes of the British Parliament and the parliaments of the Commonwealth realms, so that the demise of the Crown no longer has much legal significance.
Although the concept of the demise of the Crown originally was based on the monarch's death, it was used in 1936 to describe the transfer of the Crown to George VI upon the abdication of Edward VIII, as the Act of Parliament that gave legal effect to the abdication specified that, upon the instrument of abdication taking effect, Edward VIII would cease to be King and there would be a demise of the Crown.
Other monarchies use different terminologies for the end of a reign.
If the monarch who dies or abdicates is the Queen and her successor is the King, references to 'Queen's' automatically changes to 'King's'. For example, lawyers in the Dominions of the Crown who are Queen's Counsel (Q.C.) at the time of the demise become King's Counsel (K.C.) without any need to seek new letters patent. The reverse is also true, as was the case from 6 February 1952 upon the death of King George VI, when living King's Counsel became Queen's Counsel.
story:
In the bustling city of Fairfield, the beloved monarch, King James, had ruled for decades with grace and wisdom. His subjects adored him, and his reign was marked by prosperity and peace. However, one fateful day, tragedy struck as the King fell ill and passed away unexpectedly.

As the news of the King's demise spread throughout the kingdom, there was a somber atmosphere in Fairfield. But according to the laws of the land, upon the death of the King, the Crown automatically transferred to his eldest son, Prince William. With the demise of the Crown, all appointments made by the late King were revoked, and there was a sense of uncertainty in the air.

Amidst the mourning, Prince William was officially crowned as the new monarch, King William. As the new King ascended to the throne, the legal transition was smooth, and the kingdom started a new chapter under his rule. Lawyers who were once Queen's Counsel were now bestowed the title of King's Counsel, reflecting the change in leadership.

The demise of the Crown, while a solemn event, showcased the seamless transfer of power and the continuity of the monarchy in Fairfield. The legacy of King James lived on through his son, King William, as the kingdom embraced a new era under his reign.

definition:
In law, desuetude (; from French  désuétude, from Latin  desuetudo 'outdated, no longer custom') is a doctrine that causes statutes, similar legislation, or legal principles to lapse and become unenforceable by a long habit of non-enforcement or lapse of time.  It is what happens to laws that are not repealed when they become obsolete.  It is the legal doctrine that long and continued non-use of a law renders it invalid, at least in the sense that courts will no longer tolerate punishing its transgressors.
The policy of inserting sunset clauses into a constitution or charter of rights (as in Canada since 1982) or into regulations and other delegated/subordinate legislation made under an act (as in Australia since the early 1990s) can be regarded as a statutory codification of this jus commune doctrine.
story:
Once upon a time in a quaint town called Maplewood, an old law existed that prohibited residents from riding bicycles on the main street every Sunday. The law was put in place ages ago to prevent accidents during the busy market day.

Over the years, the town grew, and no one really remembered the origins of the law. Times changed, and Sundays turned into lazy days for the community to ride their bicycles and enjoy the fresh air. Slowly but surely, no one paid any attention to the old prohibition.

One day, a new resident moved in and decided to challenge the old law. He hopped on his shiny new bicycle and confidently rode down the main street on a Sunday. To his surprise, no one stopped him, and no one even seemed to care.

Confused, he asked the locals about the law, and they simply shrugged, saying, "Oh, that old rule? We don't really follow that anymore. It's been years since anyone bothered about it."

And that's how the concept of desuetude manifested in Maplewood. The unenforced law had become obsolete through long years of non-use, eventually fading into obscurity and becoming unenforceable.

definition: The discovery doctrine, or doctrine of discovery, is a disputed interpretation of international law during the Age of Discovery, introduced into United States municipal law by the US Supreme Court Justice John Marshall in Johnson v. McIntosh (1823). In Marshall's formulation of the doctrine, discovery of territory previously unknown to Europeans gave the discovering nation title to that territory against all other European nations, and this title could be perfected by possession. A number of legal scholars have criticized Marshall's interpretation of the relevant international law. In recent decades, advocates for Indigenous rights have campaigned against the doctrine, which purportedly stemmed from some Papal bulls. In 2023, the Roman Curia of the Vatican formally repudiated the doctrine.
story:
In the small coastal town of Seaview, a long-standing dispute erupted between the town's fishermen and a group of explorers who claimed to have discovered a hidden cove believed to be abundant in valuable fish stocks. The fishermen had been relying on these waters for generations, but the explorers argued that their discovery entitled them to exclusive rights to fish in the cove.

As tensions rose, the case made its way to the town's judgment hall, where the wise Judge Marshall presided. Upon hearing both sides, he explained the discovery doctrine to the puzzled townspeople.

Judge Marshall likened the situation to a rule in the olden days, where the first explorer to set foot on a new land could claim it as their own. While the fishermen had long used the cove, the explorers could argue that their discovery gave them ownership under the law.

However, Judge Marshall also highlighted the growing criticism and movements against this doctrine, as it disregarded the rights of those who had long inhabited the land. In the end, he urged the community to work together to find a solution that would honor both the historical use of the cove by the fishermen and the explorer's discovery.

Inspired by the judge's words, the townspeople came together to share the resources of the cove, forging a new understanding that respected both tradition and discovery.

definition:
The Doctrine of Cash Equivalence states that the U.S. Federal income tax law treats certain non-cash payment transactions like cash payment transactions for federal income tax purposes. The doctrine is used most often for deciding when cash method (as opposed to accrual method) taxpayers are to include certain non-cash income items.  Another doctrine often used when trying to determine the timing of the inclusion of income is the constructive receipt doctrine.
Most individuals begin as cash method taxpayers because their first form of bookkeeping is a checkbook. In contrast, some businesses start as accrual method taxpayers because businesses use different rules for recording income and expenditures. The Internal Revenue Code (IRC) § 446(a) states, however, that  "[t]axable income shall be computed under the method of accounting on the basis which the taxpayer regularly computes his income in keeping his books."
One of the major advantages to the cash method of accounting is the ability to defer taxation because the recognition of income applicable to amounts in accounts receivable can be deferred to a later year. The Doctrine of Cash Equivalence is important because many people are cash method taxpayers and would be subject to this rule.
story:
Sarah, a small business owner, was excited to have landed a big contract for her graphic design services. The client, impressed with her work, offered to pay her in shares of their company instead of cash. Happy about the opportunity to potentially gain from the company's success, Sarah accepted the offer.

As tax season approached, Sarah grew concerned about how to report this non-cash income on her tax return. She turned to her friend Alex, a tax accountant, for advice. Alex explained the Doctrine of Cash Equivalence to her.

"Sarah, even though you didn't receive cash, the IRS still considers those shares as income for tax purposes. The Doctrine of Cash Equivalence means that non-cash payments, like those shares, are treated as if you were paid in cash. This means you'll need to report the fair market value of the shares as income in the year you received them, even if you haven't sold them yet."

Sarah realized the importance of understanding this legal concept to ensure she filed her taxes correctly and avoided any potential issues with the IRS. Grateful for Alex's guidance, she diligently noted down this lesson for future business transactions.

definition:
In law, the doctrine of chances is a rule of evidence that allows evidence to show that it is unlikely a defendant would be repeatedly, innocently involved in similar, suspicious circumstances.
Normally, under Federal Rule of Evidence 404, evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith.
Using the doctrine of chances allows a prosecutor to admit evidence of prior "accidents" that can persuade a jury that prior incidents are so similar that it is very improbable that the case at bar is actually accidental.
The doctrine of chances was first developed by English courts in the case Rex v. Smith, 11 Cr. App. R. 229, 84 L.J.K.B. 2153 (1915), better known as the "brides in the bath murder". In this case the defendant was accused of murdering his wife by drowning her in a bath. The defendant claimed that his wife had fainted in the bath. The prosecutor sought to include evidence in the trial that the defendant's two previous wives had both died in the same way. The evidence was allowed.
story:
Sarah, a renowned pastry chef, found herself at the center of a perplexing legal case. Her business partner, Mark, had mysteriously fallen ill after consuming a dessert she had prepared for a high-profile event. Despite Sarah's insistence that it was an unfortunate accident caused by a rare allergic reaction, the authorities were skeptical.

During the investigation, it was revealed that this was not the first time someone had fallen ill after eating one of Sarah's desserts. Three years prior, a similar incident had occurred at another event she catered. Back then, the victim had also experienced a sudden allergic reaction that led to hospitalization. Sarah had attributed it to a mix-up in ingredients, and the case was closed.

As the trial unfolded, the prosecution invoked the doctrine of chances, arguing that it was too coincidental for two separate incidents to occur under similar circumstances. The evidence of the previous incident was admitted, showcasing a pattern of suspicious occurrences involving Sarah's desserts.

In the end, the jury was swayed by the repeated nature of the incidents, leading to Sarah's conviction for food tampering. The doctrine of chances had played a crucial role in unraveling the truth behind the seemingly unfortunate accidents.

definition: The doctrine of colourability is the idea that when a legislature wants to do something that it cannot do within the constraints of its government's constitution, it colours the law with a substitute purpose, allowing it to accomplish its original goal.
story:
Once in a small town named Riverview, a group of concerned citizens discovered that a new zoning law was being proposed by the local government. This law aimed to restrict the operation of food trucks in the town, much to the dismay of the food truck owners who relied on this business for their livelihood.

As the citizens delved deeper into the matter, they realized that the true intention behind the proposed law was to appease a prominent local restaurant owner who felt threatened by the popularity of the food trucks. However, restricting the food trucks directly based on this reason would be against the Constitution.

To circumvent this legal obstacle, the government colored the law with a different purpose – public health and safety concerns. They argued that food trucks posed a risk to the cleanliness and hygiene of the town, giving them the authority to regulate their operation.

The citizens, aware of the underlying motive, challenged the law in court, arguing that the government was using the doctrine of colourability to disguise their true intention of favoring the restaurant owner. Through their efforts, they were able to expose the government's subterfuge, leading to the withdrawal of the law and ensuring that justice prevailed in Riverview.

In this story, the doctrine of colourability is exemplified by the government's attempt to cloak their true motive behind a seemingly legitimate purpose to achieve their desired outcome.

definition: The doctrine of equivalents is a legal rule in many (but not all) of the world's patent systems that allows a court to hold a party liable for patent infringement if the infringing device or process does not fall within the literal scope of a patent claim but is nevertheless equivalent to the claimed invention. In the United States, Judge Learned Hand has described its purpose as being "to temper unsparing logic and prevent an infringer from stealing the benefit of the invention."
story:
In a small town, there were two neighboring toy companies, ToyTech and PlayTime Toys, known for their innovative designs. ToyTech patented a revolutionary mechanism that made their dollhouse doors open with a gentle push. PlayTime Toys, eager to replicate this success, created a similar dollhouse without infringing on ToyTech's patent claims.

Months later, ToyTech noticed that PlayTime Toys' dollhouses were selling like hotcakes, causing a decline in their own sales. Upon closer inspection, they realized that although PlayTime Toys didn't copy the exact mechanism, they used a different system that achieved the same result - opening the dollhouse doors with a gentle push.

ToyTech decided to take legal action, claiming that PlayTime Toys' product was equivalent to their patented invention, falling under the doctrine of equivalents. The case went to court, where the judge had to determine if PlayTime Toys' mechanism was indeed equivalent to ToyTech's patented design.

After careful deliberation, the judge ruled in favor of ToyTech, citing the doctrine of equivalents. Despite the differences in the mechanisms, the judge concluded that PlayTime Toys' dollhouse doors' operation was equivalent to ToyTech's patented mechanism, preventing them from benefiting from ToyTech's innovation without proper authorization.

This case demonstrated the importance of the doctrine of equivalents in protecting inventors' rights and preventing others from exploiting their innovations through subtle variations.

definition: The doctrine of exoneration of liens (sometimes simply referred to as "doctrine of exoneration") refers to a common law rule. The rule says that encumbrances (i.e. a mortgage) of a property conveyed by a will is discharged with funds from the originating estate, not from the property itself.
story:
Once upon a time in the quaint town of Willow Creek, Mrs. Thompson passed away, leaving behind a charming cottage to her son, Thomas. Little did Thomas know, the cottage came with a hidden mortgage that Mrs. Thompson had taken out years ago.

As Thomas began settling his mother's estate, he discovered the mortgage lien on the cottage. Confused and worried, he sought legal advice from the town's trusted attorney, Mr. Jenkins.

Mr. Jenkins explained the legal concept of the doctrine of exoneration of liens to Thomas. He illustrated it by saying, "Thomas, this doctrine means that the mortgage on the cottage isn't your responsibility to pay off with your own funds. Instead, the debt should be cleared using the funds from your mother's estate."

Relieved, Thomas understood that the mortgage lien would not burden his own finances. He followed Mr. Jenkins' guidance, using the funds from his mother's estate to pay off the mortgage and secure ownership of the cottage without encumbrances.

Thanks to the doctrine of exoneration of liens, Thomas was able to honor his mother's legacy without being unfairly held liable for her financial obligations. The cottage, now free from any encumbrances, stood as a symbol of Thomas' love and devotion to his late mother.

definition:
This article discusses the trademark doctrine regarding translation of foreign words. For the patent doctrine regarding equivalent means to practice an invention, see Doctrine of equivalents.

The doctrine of foreign equivalents is a rule applied in United States trademark law which requires courts and the TTAB to translate foreign words in determining whether they are registrable as trademarks, or confusingly similar with existing marks. The doctrine is intended to protect consumers within the United States from confusion or deception caused by the use of terms in different languages. In some cases, a party will use a word as a mark which is either generic or merely descriptive of the goods in a foreign language, or which shares the same meaning as an existing mark to speakers of that foreign language.
story:
Once upon a time, Maria, a young entrepreneur from a small town, decided to start her own cosmetics company. As she brainstormed names for her new line of skincare products, she stumbled upon the beautiful Italian word "Bellezza," which means beauty.

Excited about her discovery, Maria quickly filed for a trademark for "Bellezza" in the United States because she believed it perfectly captured the essence of her products.

Unbeknownst to Maria, there was already an established beauty brand in the U.S. with the name "Belezza," which sounded and looked very similar to "Bellezza." The owners of Belezza immediately filed a trademark opposition, citing the doctrine of foreign equivalents.

During the legal proceedings, it was determined that "Bellezza" and "Belezza" were essentially the same word with slight variations due to translation from Italian. The court ruled in favor of the existing brand, explaining that consumers might confuse the two names due to their similar meanings and pronunciation.

Maria learned the importance of considering the doctrine of foreign equivalents in trademark selection, realizing that even though a word may seem unique in a foreign language, it could still clash with existing trademarks in the U.S. market. She revised her brand name and continued her entrepreneurial journey, now with a deeper understanding of trademark law.

definition:
The doctrine of indivisibility (or indivisibility doctrine) was a legal doctrine in United States copyright law, which held that a copyright was a single, indivisible right that its owner could only assign as a whole.  The doctrine was founded upon the policy concern that a defendant alleged to have infringed a single work might find himself facing claims from multiple plaintiffs, all claiming copyright in that same work.  Despite the indivisibility doctrine, a copyright holder could still effectively assign certain rights.  The assignees of those rights were held to be "mere licensees."
This doctrine could yield a harsh result for an exclusive licensee in a work.  If a third party infringed the work, the copyright holder had no motivation to file suit---the work was no longer marketable.  So courts allowed exclusive licensees to compulsively join the copyright holder as a plaintiff in such suits.  Non-exclusive licensees could not forcefully join copyright holders, on the theory that in those cases, the work was still marketable and the copyright holder therefore had an interest in protecting his rights.
The doctrine could also yield a harsh result where a magazine purchased the right of first publication from an author, but provided a copyright notice only for the magazine as a whole, not for the author. This would result in a forfeiture of any copyright protection and an injection of the work into the public domain. As detailed below, this harsh result was mostly abrogated by Goodis v. United Artists Television, Inc.
In the case Goodis v. United Artists Television, Inc., 425 F.2d 397, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held that the doctrine of indivisibility could not operate to wholly deprive an author of his copyright when a "mere licensee" secured a copyright in a collective work but the author never secured a separate copyright on his own.
The doctrine of indivisibility was expressly eliminated in the Copyright Act of 1976. Assignees of rights in a copyrighted work now have standing to directly file suit against infringers. Because adequacy of a copyright notice is examined under the statue as it existed on the date that the work was first published, the doctrine of indivisibility remains potentially relevant for works published before January 1, 1978.
story:
Once upon a time in a quaint little town, there lived two talented siblings, Maya and Alex. Maya was a gifted writer, while Alex had a flair for illustration. Together, they created a beautiful children's book that was quickly recognized for its creativity and charm.

Excited about their creation, Maya and Alex decided to grant an exclusive license to a local publisher, Bright Pages Publishing, for the right to print and distribute their book. However, when the book hit the shelves, Maya and Alex were shocked to discover that the publisher had failed to include their names in the copyright notice. Instead, only Bright Pages Publishing was credited.

As the book gained popularity, a well-known toy company, Playful Creations, decided to create a line of toys inspired by the characters in Maya and Alex's book. Seeing the opportunity slip away, Maya and Alex sought legal advice, only to learn about the doctrine of indivisibility.

Under this legal concept, since Maya and Alex had granted an exclusive license without retaining any separate copyright rights for themselves, they were considered mere licensees and had limited legal standing to pursue a copyright infringement claim against Playful Creations. They were left feeling helpless as their beloved creation seemed to slip out of their hands.

In the end, with the help of a skilled copyright attorney, Maya and Alex were able to navigate the complexities of the law and secure their rights to the book. The siblings learned a valuable lesson about the importance of understanding copyright law and ensuring their creative works were legally protected.

definition:
In United States patent law, the doctrine of inherency holds that, under certain circumstances, prior art may be relied upon not only for what it expressly teaches, but also for what is inherent therein, i.e., what necessarily flows from the express teachings. For a patent claim to be valid, its subject-matter must be novel and non-obvious. The claim is anticipated (i.e. will fail because its subject-matter is not novel) if a single prior art reference, either expressly or inherently, discloses every feature of the claimed invention. The concept of inherency is predicated on the idea that a claim should not pass the test of anticipation merely because a feature of it is undisclosed or unrecognized in the prior art reference. A prior art source may thus still anticipate if an apparently missing element of the claim is inherent in that prior art source.
Procedurally, to rely on the doctrine of inherency, one must provide a basis in fact and/or technical reasoning supporting a determination that an allegedly inherent characteristic necessarily would be present if the teachings of the prior art were followed, even if the inherent feature would not have been recognized.
The fact that a certain result or characteristic may occur or be present in the prior art is not alone sufficient to establish the inherency of that result or characteristic. To establish inherency, the evidence must make clear that the missing matter is necessarily present in the prior art reference.  Inherency may not be established by probabilities or possibilities.
Once the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) establishes that a product referenced in prior art appears to be substantially identical, the burden shifts to the applicant to show a non-obvious difference.
The doctrine of inherency is typically invoked when an inventor tries to obtain a product patent for a product that had been unintentionally invented earlier ("accidental anticipation").
The United States Supreme Court held in Tilghman v. Proctor that where the first, accidental producer was not aware of the product and did not attempt to produce it, the first production did not bar a patent on the subsequent "invention" of the product. 102 U.S. 707 (1880).
The use of the doctrine of inherency in a determination of obviousness is more complicated because "[t]hat which may be inherent is not necessarily known and that which is unknown cannot be obvious."
A patent applicant may use the doctrine of inherency to respond to a rejection for lack of an adequate written description by showing that the patent application inherently includes the disclosure that is allegedly lacking.
story:
Once upon a time, in a bustling town known for its unique inventions, lived two friends, Lily and Max. Lily, a talented inventor, had been working on creating a new type of environmentally friendly fuel for months. One day, while tinkering in her workshop, she accidentally spilled a combination of ingredients that created the perfect formula for the fuel she had been dreaming of.

Unbeknownst to Lily, Max, a curious inventor himself, had been working on a similar fuel formula in his own workshop. Coincidentally, his formula turned out to be identical to Lily's, but he had not yet discovered it.

When Lily excitedly shared her accidental invention with Max, he was amazed at how their formulas were identical. Concerned that they couldn't both patent the same invention, they sought the advice of a patent attorney.

The attorney explained the concept of inherency to Lily and Max, emphasizing that even though Max had not intentionally created the fuel, it was still considered inherent in his prior work. The attorney advised Lily to pursue the patent application, as the accidental anticipation of the invention did not prevent her from obtaining the patent.

In the end, Lily successfully patented her environmentally friendly fuel, showcasing how the doctrine of inherency could protect inventors in cases of accidental discoveries.

definition:
The exhaustion of intellectual property rights constitutes one of the limits of intellectual property (IP) rights. Once a given product has been sold under the authorization of the IP owner, the reselling, rental, lending and other third party commercial uses of IP-protected goods in domestic and international markets are governed by the principle.
After a product covered by an IP right, such as by a patent right, has been sold by the IP right owner or by others with the consent of the owner, the IP right is said to be exhausted. It can no longer be exercised by the owner. This limitation is also referred to as the exhaustion doctrine or first sale doctrine. For example, if an inventor obtains a patent on a new kind of umbrella, the inventor (or anyone else to whom he sells his patent) can legally prohibit other companies from making and selling this kind of umbrella, but cannot prohibit customers who have bought this umbrella from the patent owner from reselling the umbrella to third parties. Or if a piece of software containing a patented algorithm is distributed by the patent owner, then the patent is exhausted.
While there is a "fairly broad consensus" throughout the world that patent exhaustion "applies at least within the context of the domestic market", "[t]here is less consensus as to what extent the sale of an IP protected product abroad can exhaust the IP rights over this product in the context of domestic law." The former is the concept of "national exhaustion", the latter of "regional exhaustion" or "international exhaustion". The rules and legal implications of the exhaustion largely differ depending on the country of importation, i.e. the national jurisdiction.
The legal concept of international exhaustion is much more controversial, and is recognized in some countries but not in others. The importation, in a country that recognizes the concept of international exhaustion, of a product sold in a foreign country with the authorization of the IP right owner cannot be prevented by the IP right owner. The Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS), an international agreement administered by the World Trade Organization (WTO), does not address the issue of exhaustion of intellectual property rights.
Brexit in 2020 caused restrictions on trade out of the UK, creating an asymmetric exhaustion status enabling imports to the UK from the EEA where there is no matching opportunity for parallel exports from the UK to the EEA. This was thought in February 2022 to be likely to continue for some time, or even indefinitely.
story:
Once upon a time, in a quaint town named Evergreen, where Lily ran a small bookstore. She loved sharing stories and knowledge with her community. One day, Lily's shop received a shipment of the latest best-selling novels from a publisher in the European Union.

Excited to share these new books with her customers, Lily displayed them prominently in her store. The books sold like hotcakes, and soon, her shelves were empty. A few weeks later, Lily received a letter from the publisher, demanding that she stop selling those books or face legal action. Confused and worried, Lily sought legal advice.

It turned out that the legal concept at play was the Doctrine of International Exhaustion. In this case, because Lily had purchased the books from an authorized distributor in the European Union, the publisher could not prevent her from selling them in her bookstore in Evergreen, despite the publisher's rights in the European Union.

As Lily learned more about this concept, she realized that the laws around intellectual property rights can vary from country to country. The situation highlighted how legal complexities could impact businesses like hers, leading to a newfound appreciation for the importance of understanding international legal principles.

definition:
In common-law legal systems, laches ( LAT-chiz, ;  Law French: remissness, dilatoriness, from Old French: laschesse) is a lack of diligence and activity in making a legal claim, or moving forward with legal enforcement of a right, particularly in regard to  equity. It is an unreasonable delay that can be viewed as prejudicing the opposing party. When asserted in litigation, it is an equity defense, that is, a defense to a claim for an equitable remedy.  It is often understood in comparison to a statute of limitations, a statutory defense, which traditionally is a defense to a claim "at law".
The person invoking laches is asserting that an opposing party has "slept on its rights", and that, as a result of this delay, circumstances have changed (witnesses or evidence may have been lost or no longer available, etc.), such that it is no longer a just resolution to grant the plaintiff's claim. Laches is associated with the maxim of equity: "Equity aids the vigilant" – not those who sleep on their rights. Put another way, failure to assert one's rights in a timely manner can result in a claim being barred by laches.
story:
In a quaint neighborhood, Mrs. Thompson had a beautiful garden that she tended to lovingly for years. Next door, Mr. Jenkins admired her garden but always dreamed of expanding his own property. One summer afternoon, Mrs. Thompson noticed Mr. Jenkins tearing down the fence between their properties and extending his yard into her garden.

Shocked, Mrs. Thompson confronted Mr. Jenkins, who claimed that he had always wanted more space and thought she wouldn't mind. Mrs. Thompson, taken aback by his audacity, decided to consult a lawyer and take legal action against him for trespassing and property infringement.

Months passed, with Mrs. Thompson collecting evidence and building her case. However, when she finally filed a lawsuit against Mr. Jenkins, he invoked the doctrine of laches. He argued that Mrs. Thompson had known about his encroachment for a long time but had done nothing about it promptly, allowing him to invest time and effort in expanding his property.

The court considered the delay in Mrs. Thompson's legal action and the prejudice it caused Mr. Jenkins since he had already made substantial changes to his property. In the end, the court ruled in favor of Mr. Jenkins, citing that Mrs. Thompson had slept on her rights, and her claim was barred by laches. The once vibrant garden now stood divided by a new fence, a lasting reminder of the consequences of delayed legal action.

definition:
The doctrine of necessity is the basis on which extraordinary actions by administrative authority, which are designed to restore order or uphold fundamental constitutional principles, are considered to be lawful even if such an action contravenes established constitution, laws, norms, or conventions. The maxim on which the doctrine is based originated in the writings of the medieval jurist Henry de Bracton, and similar justifications for this kind of extra-legal action have been advanced by more recent legal authorities, including William Blackstone.
In a controversial 1954 judgment, Pakistani Chief Justice Muhammad Munir validated the extra-constitutional use of emergency powers by Governor General, Ghulam Mohammad. In his judgment, the Chief Justice cited Bracton's maxim, 'that which is otherwise not lawful is made lawful by necessity', thereby providing the label that would come to be attached to the judgment and the doctrine that it was establishing.
The doctrine of necessity may also refer to the necessity of a judge with a reasonable apprehension of bias continuing to decide a matter if there is no alternative to that judge. The Supreme Court of Canada applied this doctrine in the 1998 Reference re Remuneration of Judges (No 2) case.
story:
In the small town of Oakwood, a severe storm hit, knocking down power lines and cutting off all communication. The town's only bridge, crucial for accessing vital supplies, collapsed due to the heavy rain. With no immediate way to repair it, the town faced a crisis.

The Mayor, Sarah, knew that under normal circumstances, fixing the bridge without following the proper legal procedures would be unlawful. However, with supplies dwindling and no way in or out of the town, she invoked the doctrine of necessity.

Mayor Sarah called an emergency town meeting and explained the situation. The townspeople, understanding the gravity of the situation, supported her decision to temporarily bypass the usual legal channels to repair the bridge. Together, they worked tirelessly to ensure the bridge was repaired quickly, allowing access to much-needed supplies and emergency services.

After the crisis had passed, some questioned Mayor Sarah's actions, citing legal concerns. However, the town council unanimously agreed that in the face of necessity, extraordinary actions were justified to protect the well-being of the community.

And so, the doctrine of necessity in Oakwood became a symbol of unity and pragmatism in times of crisis, illustrating that sometimes legal norms must yield to the greater good.

definition:
The doctrine of non-derogation from grants is a principle of the law of England and Wales. As the House of Lords explained in British Leyland Motor Corp v Armstrong Patents Co, it states that a seller of realty or goods is not permitted to take any action (such as bringing an infringement action) that will lessen the value to the buyer of the thing sold.
United States federal law recognises similar doctrines such as the exhaustion doctrine or doctrine of implied license. A similar effect has also been realised in United States patent law under the doctrine of repair and reconstruction.
An important difference between the doctrine of non-derogation from grants and other doctrines, particularly implied license, that are used to accomplish similar results is that the doctrine of non-derogation from grants is "inherent" as a matter of property law and apparently cannot be avoided by a seller's use of language attempting to negative application of the doctrine or by trial counsel's pointing to evidence of intent not to relinquish patent rights or copyright. In contrast, the other doctrines may be vulnerable to contractual disclaimers or evidence of intent not to grant intellectual property rights. The issue is discussed to some extent in the courts' opinions in British Leyland and Quanta Computer, Inc. v. LG Electronics, Inc.
story:
Once upon a time, in the quaint town of Maplewood, there lived a skilled carpenter named Sam. Sam had a small workshop where he crafted beautiful wooden furniture, from intricately carved tables to sturdy chairs.

One day, Sam received a visit from a wealthy merchant named Mr. Smith. Impressed by Sam's craftsmanship, Mr. Smith commissioned a set of custom-made dining chairs for his grand estate. After weeks of hard work, Sam proudly presented the completed chairs to Mr. Smith.

However, a few months later, Sam was shocked to learn that Mr. Smith had filed a lawsuit against him, claiming that the chairs infringed on a patent he held for a unique design. Sam was devastated, fearing he would lose everything he had worked so hard to build.

But then, Sam's wise old neighbor, Martha, who had years of experience in legal matters, came to his aid. She explained to Sam the legal concept of 'Doctrine of non-derogation from grants', which meant that Mr. Smith couldn't take any action that would diminish the value of what he had sold to Sam - in this case, the chairs.

Armed with this knowledge, Sam's lawyer successfully defended him in court, citing the doctrine to protect Sam's rights as the buyer of the chairs. In the end, justice prevailed, and Sam could continue creating his beautiful furniture without fear of unwarranted legal threats.

definition:
The doctrine of privity of contract is a common law principle which provides that a contract cannot confer rights or impose obligations upon anyone who is not a party to that contract. It is related to, but distinct from, the doctrine of consideration, according to which a promise is legally enforceable only if valid consideration has been provided for it, and a plaintiff is legally entitled to enforce such a promise only if they are a promisee from whom the consideration has moved.
A principal consequence of the doctrine of privity is that, at common law, a third party generally has no right to enforce a contract to which they are not a party, even where that contract was entered into by the contracting parties specifically for their benefit and with a common intention among all of them that they should be able to enforce it.  In England & Wales and Northern Ireland, the doctrine has been substantially weakened by the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999, which created a statutory exception to privity, providing, in certain circumstances, third parties the right to enforce terms of contracts to which they are not privy.
story:
Once upon a time in a small town, Sarah hired a contractor, Mark, to renovate her old farmhouse. Their contract included a clause that specified the use of high-quality materials for the project, ensuring longevity and durability. During the renovation, Mark subcontracted the electrical work to a third-party electrician, John, to meet the project deadline.

One stormy night, a severe lightning strike caused a short circuit in the farmhouse's electrical system, resulting in significant damage. Sarah discovered that the wiring was poorly done and the substandard materials used by John were to blame for the electrical failure. Furious, she demanded compensation from Mark for the damages.

However, Mark pointed out that the contract was solely between him and Sarah, and that John, as a third party sub-contractor, was not directly bound by the terms of their agreement. Despite Sarah’s arguments that the contract was intended for her benefit and that she should be able to hold John accountable, the doctrine of privity of contract prevented her from pursuing legal action against him.

In the end, Sarah had to bear the costs of repairing the damage caused by John's negligence, learning the hard way about the limitations imposed by the doctrine of privity in contractual relationships.

definition:
The doctrine of repair and reconstruction in United States patent law distinguishes between permissible repair of a patented article, which the right of an owner of property to preserve its utility and operability guarantees, and impermissible reconstruction of a patented article, which is patent infringement. The doctrine is explained in Aro Mfg. Co. v. Convertible Top Replacement Co. The Aro case states the rule in these terms:

The decisions of this Court require the conclusion that reconstruction of a patented entity, comprised of unpatented elements, is limited to such a true reconstruction of the entity as to "in fact make a new article," after the entity, viewed as a whole, has become spent. In order to call the monopoly, conferred by the patent grant, into play for a second time, it must, indeed, be a second creation of the patented entity. …Mere replacement of individual unpatented parts, one at a time, whether of the same part repeatedly or different parts successively, is no more than the lawful right of the owner to repair his property.

An extension  of the doctrine is a right to modify the product to enhance its functionality, such as to make it operate faster or with a different size of product. The Supreme Court said in Wilbur-Ellis Co. v. Kuther that such a right was "kin  to repair for it bore on the useful capacity of the old combination, on which the royalty had been paid."
The House of Lords declared a similar principle—the doctrine of non-derogation from grants—concerning car owners' repair and replacement of automobile parts, in British Leyland Motor Corp. v. Armstrong Patents Co.
story:
Once upon a time in a small town, there was a skilled craftsman named Alex who owned a unique patented clock that was known for its precise timekeeping. One day, the clock's mechanism started malfunctioning, making it lose its accuracy. Concerned, Alex decided to fix it himself.

Alex carefully examined the clock and realized that a few gears within the mechanism needed to be replaced to restore its proper functioning. Remembering the legal concept he had heard about, the Doctrine of repair and reconstruction, Alex understood that he had the right to repair his patented clock.

Following the guidance of the legal principle, Alex replaced the worn-out gears with new ones, ensuring that he maintained the clock's original design and purpose. By doing so, he upheld the distinction between permissible repair and impermissible reconstruction as outlined in the Aro case.

As Alex successfully repaired his clock and restored it to its former glory, he not only fulfilled his obligation as the owner but also respected the boundaries set by patent law. In the end, the ticking of the clock resumed, signaling that through understanding legal principles like the Doctrine of repair and reconstruction, one could navigate challenges while upholding the sanctity of patented inventions.

definition:
Res judicata or res iudicata, also known as claim preclusion, is the Latin term for judged matter, and refers to either of two concepts in common law civil procedure: a case in which there has been a final judgment and that is no longer subject to appeal; and the legal doctrine meant to bar (or preclude) relitigation of a claim between the same parties.
In the case of res judicata, the matter cannot be raised again, either in the same court or in a different court. A court will use res judicata to deny reconsideration of a matter. The doctrine of res judicata is a method of preventing injustice to the parties of a case supposedly finished but perhaps also or mostly a way of avoiding unnecessary waste of judicial resources. Res judicata does not merely prevent future judgments from contradicting earlier ones, but also prevents litigants from multiplying judgments.
It is similar to the concept of double jeopardy and non bis in idem in criminal law, but the protection in criminal prosecutions only bars an identical prosecution for the same offense. However, a different offense may be charged on identical evidence at a second trial; whereas, res judicata precludes any causes of action or claims that may arise from the previously litigated subject matter.
story:
In a quaint town named Willow Creek, two neighbors, Jake and Sarah, found themselves embroiled in a heated dispute over a small strip of land between their properties. Jake claimed the land was his based on an old deed, while Sarah argued that it belonged to her family for generations.

Seeking resolution, they took their case to the local court where a judge carefully considered all evidence and arguments presented. After thorough deliberation, the judge ruled in favor of Jake, declaring him the rightful owner of the disputed land. Sarah was understandably upset but accepted the court's decision.

Months later, tensions flared up again when Sarah decided to take Jake to court once more, this time with new evidence she believed would prove her ownership. However, to Sarah's dismay, the judge swiftly dismissed her case, citing the doctrine of res judicata. The judge explained that since the matter had already been litigated and a final judgment had been made, Sarah was not permitted to bring the same claim before the court again.

Jake, relieved that the legal system prevented him from enduring a redundant and costly legal battle, graciously offered to mediate their differences outside of court. And so, with the doctrine of res judicata serving as a shield against unnecessary litigation, Jake and Sarah found a way to peacefully coexist as neighbors in Willow Creek.

definition:
In common law systems, land tenure, from the French verb "tenir" means "to hold", is the legal regime in which land "owned" by an individual is possessed by someone else who is said to "hold" the land, based on an agreement between both individuals. It determines who can use land, for how long and under what conditions. Tenure may be based both on official laws and policies, and on informal local customs (insofar higher law does allow that).  In other words, land tenure implies a system according to which land is held by an individual or the actual tiller of the land but this person does not have legal ownership.
It determines the holder's rights and responsibilities in connection with their holding. The sovereign monarch, known in England as the Crown, held land in its own right. All land holders are either its tenants or sub-tenants. Tenure signifies a legal relationship between tenant and lord, arranging the duties and rights of tenant and lord in relationship to the land. Over history, many different forms of land tenure, i.e., ways of holding land, have been established.
A landowner is the holder of the estate in land with the most extensive and exclusive rights of ownership over the territory, simply put, the owner of land.
story:
Once upon a time in the small town of Willow Creek, there lived a farmer named Jack who had been tending to a piece of land passed down through generations. The land, however, technically belonged to the royal family, represented by the noble Lady Arabella.

Under the Doctrine of Tenure, Jack was considered a tenant of the Crown, which meant he held the land with permission from Lady Arabella.
