Dailey (1955), the Washington Supreme Court remanded a case back to the lower courts to determine whether or not the five year-old defendant "knew with substantial certainty that the plaintiff would attempt to sit down where the chair which he moved had been."
story:
In a bustling café, Lily, a diligent waitress, rushes around balancing trays of steaming coffee and plates of delicious pastries. One busy morning, she spots a wobbly chair at a vacant table and quickly moves it to the side to prevent a customer from accidentally falling.

Unbeknownst to Lily, a mischievous young boy named Timmy, who is known for playing pranks, sees her move the chair. Seizing the opportunity for mischief, Timmy quietly repositions the chair directly behind the unsuspecting café owner, Mr. Johnson.

As Mr. Johnson turns around to sit down after a long day’s work, he lands on the chair that Timmy has moved. With a loud crash, Mr. Johnson hits the floor, causing a ruckus in the café.

Despite not intending for Mr. Johnson to fall, Timmy knew with substantial certainty that someone would attempt to sit on the chair after witnessing Lily move it. His deliberate act creates a situation where the outcome was foreseeable, leading to Mr. Johnson's fall.

In this scenario, the substantial certainty doctrine would come into play to determine whether Timmy’s actions constitute a tort, as he knowingly set the stage for an accident to occur.

definition:
At common law, substantial performance is an alternative principle to the perfect tender rule. It allows a court to imply a term that allows a partial or substantially similar performance to stand in for the performance specified in the contract.
This principle is relevant when a contractor's performance is in some way deficient, through no willful act by the contractor, yet is so nearly equivalent that it would be unreasonable for the owner to deny the agreed upon payment. If a contractor successfully demonstrates substantial performance, the owner remains obligated to fulfill payment, less any damages suffered as a result of the deficiencies in workmanship by the contractor.
The principle is also found in the law of unilateral contracts. Unilateral contracts are contracts in which one party offers a promise in exchange for an actual performance. Traditionally, such contracts were deemed to be effective once the specified performance was tendered, and could be revoked at any time prior to completion of the performance, presenting the notorious "Cedric Brooklyn Bridge problem": in theory, A could say to B "I'll give you $100 if you walk across the Brooklyn Bridge", and then, just before B finishes crossing, pull up to him in a car and say "The deal is off," at which point no contract would be formed and A would not be liable to B for anything. This result was deemed unacceptable by many jurists and legal scholars, and applied the doctrine of substantial performance to this situation, effectively deeming someone who had begun the performance to have established an option contract to hold the unilateral contract open. This principle is enunciated in Section 237 of the Restatement (Second) of Contracts.
story:
Alice, a homeowner, hired Bob, a contractor, to renovate her kitchen. They agreed on a completion date and a total cost for the project. Bob started the work promptly, but encountered some unexpected delays due to supply chain issues beyond his control.

Despite the setbacks, Bob worked diligently to finish the project as soon as possible. When he presented the completed kitchen to Alice, she noticed a few minor details that needed fixing. Bob acknowledged the issues and offered to rectify them promptly.

Alice, however, was impatient and reluctant to pay Bob the full amount, citing the imperfections in the kitchen. Bob explained the concept of substantial performance, emphasizing that the work he had done was substantially equivalent to what was agreed upon in the contract. He assured Alice that he was willing to make the necessary corrections to meet her expectations.

After much discussion, Alice realized that Bob's performance was indeed close to what was expected, and the deficiencies were minor in nature. Understanding the legal principle of substantial performance, Alice paid Bob the agreed amount, deducting only a portion for the minor fixes needed.

In the end, both Alice and Bob were content with the resolution, showcasing how the legal concept of substantial performance allows for fairness and reasonableness in contract disputes.

definition: Substantial truth is a legal doctrine affecting libel and slander laws in common law jurisdictions such as the United States or the United Kingdom.
story:
In a small town named Willow Creek, a local bakery, Sweet Delights, found itself at the center of a controversy. Rumors began spreading that their famous apple pies were made with spoiled fruits, causing patrons to fall ill.

The rumors reached a local newspaper, The Gazette, which published an article with the headline "Sweet Delights' Apple Pies Poisoning Customers?" The bakery owner, Mrs. Thompson, was devastated by the allegations and decided to take legal action for defamation.

During the court proceedings, the newspaper's lawyer argued that while the headline may have been sensationalized, the article's main point was substantially true. Investigations revealed that a few customers did report feeling unwell after consuming the apple pies, though no concrete evidence linked it to spoiled fruits.

The judge, after considering the evidence, ruled in favor of The Gazette, citing the substantial truth doctrine. While the headline may have been exaggerated, the overall gist of the article – that some customers fell ill after eating the pies – was found to be substantially true based on the evidence presented.

Mrs. Thompson, though disappointed, learned a valuable lesson about the impact of misinformation and the legal concept of substantial truth in defamation cases.

definition:
Sufficient similarity is a 20th-century para-legal concept used in the chemical industry for toxicological studies. The term was first employed in a restricted sense to assess surrogacy of chemical mixtures by the EPA, and has descended from there into the scientific argot.
The concept is somewhat nebulous, and statistics are involved. A group of America researchers in 2018 posed themselves the question how similar must a product be in order to be well-represented by the tested reference sample? Because the concept was derived from the EPA, chemical similarity and biological similarity are equally important. The concept is employed "so that safety data from the tested reference can be applied to untested materials," because "when toxicity data are not available for a chemical mixture of concern, US EPA guidelines allow risk assessment to be based on data for a surrogate mixture considered “sufficiently similar” in terms of chemical composition and component proportions."
story:
In the sleepy town of Rivertown, there was a popular family-owned bakery called Sweet Delights. Mrs. Thompson, the head baker, prided herself on her secret recipe for the world-famous chocolate chip cookies. One day, a big corporation called Global Treats opened a new bakery across the street, and soon, rumors spread that they were selling cookies strikingly similar to Sweet Delights'.

Mrs. Thompson was concerned about her recipe and decided to take legal action. She consulted with a local attorney, Mr. Greene, who explained the concept of 'sufficient similarity' to her. He likened it to the need for a reference sample in a toxicological study. Mr. Greene told Mrs. Thompson that in order to prove that Global Treats' cookies were too similar to hers, they needed to demonstrate that the ingredients, proportions, and overall composition were sufficiently alike.

Armed with this knowledge, Mrs. Thompson and Mr. Greene embarked on gathering evidence. They analyzed the recipes, ingredients, and even conducted taste tests. They found enough similarities in the recipes to convince the court that Global Treats had indeed copied Sweet Delights' recipe.

Thanks to the concept of 'sufficient similarity,' Mrs. Thompson successfully defended her secret recipe and continued delighting customers with her original chocolate chip cookies, ensuring that her hard work and creativity were protected in the face of imitators.

definition: In United States constitutional law, a suspect classification is a class or group of persons meeting a series of criteria suggesting they are likely the subject of discrimination. These classes receive closer scrutiny by courts when an Equal Protection claim alleging unconstitutional discrimination is asserted against a law, regulation, or other government action, or sometimes private action. When a law or government action affects a group that falls under a "suspect classification," courts apply the strict scrutiny standard in reviewing the constitutional validity of a law or action.
story:
In the small town of Willow Creek, there was a bakery owned by Mrs. Garcia, a kind-hearted woman loved by all in the community. One day, the town council passed a new ordinance prohibiting businesses from operating on weekends. While this regulation seemed fair to most, it had a disproportionate impact on Mrs. Garcia's bakery.

As a devout Seventh-day Adventist, Mrs. Garcia observed the Sabbath on Saturdays and kept her bakery open on Sundays instead. Her religious beliefs dictated her schedule, but the new law forced her to close her business entirely on weekends, significantly reducing her income.

Feeling unfairly targeted, Mrs. Garcia filed a lawsuit against the town council, arguing that the ordinance discriminated against a suspect classification - individuals with religious beliefs requiring them to rest on a specific day. The court acknowledged that religious groups were historically subjected to discrimination and oppression, thus warranting heightened scrutiny in legal matters.

Ultimately, the court determined that the town council's ordinance unlawfully discriminated against Mrs. Garcia's suspect classification based on her religious beliefs. The strict scrutiny standard was applied, and the ordinance was overturned, ensuring Mrs. Garcia's right to practice her religion without undue government interference.

definition:
Taint is a term used in the legal field with reference to evidence that has been "tainted" or ruined in some manner. The most common of such usage is with reference to evidence, testimony, identification by witnesses, or confessions that have been obtained by law enforcement illegally. The illegality usually results from a violation of one's constitutional rights, such as a violation of the Fourth Amendment of the Constitution protecting against unreasonable search and seizure. For example, the dissent in the Supreme Court decision of Missouri v. Seibert stated that "the court must examine whether the taint dissipated through the passing of time ... ." Missouri v. Seibert, 542 U.S. 600, 628 (U.S. 2004) (Justice O'Connor Dissent, emphasis added). The court in Wong Sun v. U.S., discussed "purg[ing] of the primary taint" with reference to allowing evidence because the defendant's statements were voluntary and a lengthy period of time had passed as an intervening act. Wong Sun v. U.S., 371 U.S. 471, (1963) (quoting J. Maguire, Evidence of Guilt 221 (1959) (emphasis added) (stating: "... by means sufficiently distinguishable to be purged of the primary taint.")).
Investigators sometimes employ a "filter team," or "taint team," composed of individuals not involved in an investigation, to prevent investigators from seeing information that could taint evidence, such as information protected by attorney-client privilege.
story:
In a bustling city, Alice, a hardworking lawyer, found herself representing a client accused of a serious crime. As the case progressed, crucial evidence surfaced that could potentially turn the tide in her client's favor. However, there was a catch – the evidence had been obtained through an illegal search conducted by law enforcement.

Knowing that this evidence was tainted due to the Fourth Amendment violation, Alice faced a dilemma. She understood that using this tainted evidence in court could jeopardize the entire case and violate her client's constitutional rights. Determined to uphold the law, she reached out to a trusted taint team, a group of impartial individuals separate from the investigation, to sift through the evidence and ensure that only admissible information reached her.

Through the careful work of the taint team, they were able to identify and set aside the tainted evidence, allowing Alice to present a strong and legally sound case in court. Despite the initial setback, Alice's commitment to justice and adherence to legal principles prevailed, ultimately leading to a fair outcome for her client. The concept of taint had been navigated effectively, proving once again the importance of upholding constitutional rights in the legal system.

definition: The Tea Rose-Rectanus doctrine or remote, good-faith user doctrine is a common law rule of United States trademark law that determines the geographic scope of rights.  The doctrine allows a junior user of a mark that is geographically remote from the senior user of the mark to establish priority over a senior user's claim to the mark in the junior user's area.  The constructive use and notice sections of the Lanham Act limited the applicability of this doctrine.
story:
Once upon a time in the small town of Willow Creek, two family-owned bakeries unknowingly found themselves in a trademark dispute over the name "Sweet Harvest."

The Smith family had been operating Sweet Harvest Bakery for decades, known for their delectable apple pies and friendly service. Meanwhile, the Jones family, who had recently moved to Willow Creek from a distant town, decided to open their own bakery and named it Sweet Harvest Treats.

As the Jones family's business grew, the Smiths grew concerned about the potential confusion between the two bakeries. They decided to take legal action, claiming that the Jones family was infringing on their trademark.

However, the court applied the Tea Rose-Rectanus doctrine in this case. Since the Jones family had opened their bakery in good faith and were geographically remote from the Smith family, the doctrine allowed the Jones family to establish priority over the Sweet Harvest trademark in Willow Creek.

Despite the initial confusion, both bakeries thrived in Willow Creek, each offering their unique treats to the locals. The legal concept of the Tea Rose-Rectanus doctrine had helped resolve the trademark dispute fairly, allowing both families to continue their sweet traditions in peace.

definition: The tender years doctrine is a legal principle in family law since the late 19th century. In common law, it presumes that during a child's "tender" years (generally regarded as the age of four and under), the mother should have custody of the child. The doctrine often arises in divorce proceedings.
story:
Sarah and John had been married for five years when they decided to divorce. Their daughter, Lily, was just three years old at the time. As they navigated the complexities of splitting their assets and determining custody arrangements, the tender years doctrine became a point of contention.

Sarah argued that because Lily was still in her "tender years," she should have primary custody. She pointed to research indicating the importance of a mother's bond with a young child for their emotional development. John, on the other hand, believed that he was just as capable of caring for Lily and should have equal parenting rights.

As the case went to court, the judge considered Lily's age and the principle of the tender years doctrine. Understanding that young children often rely heavily on their mothers for care and nurturing, the judge ruled in favor of Sarah having primary custody while allowing John visitation rights.

While John was initially disappointed, he came to understand the rationale behind the tender years doctrine and the importance of considering what is in the best interests of the child during such a sensitive time. In the end, both parents made a commitment to co-parenting Lily in her best interest, despite the challenges they faced.

definition:
Terra nullius (, plural terrae nullius) is a Latin expression meaning "nobody's land".
Since the nineteenth century it has occasionally been used in international law as a principle to justify claims that territory may be acquired by a state's occupation of it. There are currently three territories sometimes claimed to be terra nullius: Bir Tawil (a strip of land between Egypt and the Sudan), four pockets of land near the Danube due to the Croatia–Serbia border dispute, and parts of Antarctica, principally Marie Byrd Land.
story:
In a small, secluded valley nestled between two mountain ranges, there lived a community of farmers who tended to their crops and livestock with great care. For generations, they had thrived in harmony with the land they called home. One day, a group of explorers from a distant kingdom stumbled upon this valley, believing it to be uninhabited and thus, terra nullius.

The explorers saw the fertile soil and abundant resources and decided to stake their claim on the valley, asserting that it belonged to no one. Ignoring the protests of the farmers, they began building fences and planting flags, declaring themselves the rightful owners.

The farmers, shocked and dismayed, sought the counsel of a wise old arbitrator known for his knowledge of ancient laws. He listened to their plight and explained the concept of terra nullius to them – the notion that land could be claimed by a state through occupation, even if it was already inhabited.

Realizing the legal loophole that the explorers were exploiting, the farmers banded together and presented their case to the kingdom's court of justice. With the arbitrator's guidance, they argued that their continued presence and use of the land should override the explorers' claim of terra nullius.

In the end, the court ruled in favor of the farmers, recognizing their longstanding connection to the valley and affirming that it was not truly nobody's land. The concept of terra nullius had been clarified and the farmers could once again cultivate their fields in peace, their rights to the land secure.

definition:
The territorial principle (also territoriality principle) is a principle of public international law which enables a sovereign state to exercise exclusive jurisdiction over individuals and other legal persons within its territory. It includes both the right to prosecute individuals for criminal offences committed within its borders, as well as the right to arrest and apprehend individuals within its territory. Its corollary bars states from exercising jurisdiction within the territory of other states without their express consent, unless such an exercise can be based on other principles of jurisdiction, such as the principle of nationality, the passive personality principle, the protective principle, and possibly, the principle of universal jurisdiction.
The Lotus case was a key court ruling on the territoriality principle. In 1926, a French vessel collided with a Turkish vessel, causing the death of several Turkish nationals. The Permanent Court of International Justice ruled, by a bare majority, that Turkey had jurisdiction to try the French naval lieutenant for criminal negligence, even though the incident happened beyond Turkey's boundaries. This case extended the territoriality principle to cover cases that happen outside a state's boundaries, but have a substantial effect on the state's interests or involve its citizens.
Questions have surfaced regarding how the territoriality principle applies with the rise of globalization and the Internet. The applicability of this principle was in question with the case against Augusto Pinochet and other cases of transnational justice.
story:
In the bustling city of Metropolis, a renowned hacker named Alex found himself in a legal predicament that put the territorial principle to the test. Alex, a citizen of Metropolis, conducted a cyber-attack that caused widespread disruption to the critical infrastructure of neighboring country, Rivertown.

As the cyber-attack crossed international borders, questions arose about which country had the right to prosecute Alex for his actions. Metropolis argued that since Alex was physically present within their territory when he initiated the attack, they should have jurisdiction to prosecute him. However, Rivertown insisted that the impact of the attack on their citizens and infrastructure gave them the right to seek justice for the harm caused.

After much deliberation and legal wrangling, an agreement was reached between Metropolis and Rivertown. They jointly prosecuted Alex under the principle of territoriality, recognizing that the cyber-attack originated from Metropolis but had far-reaching consequences in Rivertown. This case highlighted the complex nature of jurisdiction in a globalized world, where actions taken within a country's borders can have significant effects beyond those borders, leading to shared responsibility for dispensing justice.

definition:
The Tipsy Coachman doctrine is a rule of law that upholds in a higher court a correct conclusion, despite flawed reasoning by the judge in a lower court. In other words, the lower judgment was right but for the wrong reason.
The colorful "tipsy coachman" label comes from a 19th-century Georgia case, Lee v. Porter, 63 Ga 345, 346 (1879), in which the Georgia Supreme Court, noting that the "human mind is so constituted that in many instances it finds the truth when wholly unable to find the way that leads to it", quoted from Oliver Goldsmith's Retaliation: A Poem written in 1774:

The Florida Supreme Court explained the doctrine in a 2002 appeal from a second-degree murder conviction:

We start with the proposition that generally, if a claim is not raised in the [trial] court, it will not be considered on appeal. However, notwithstanding this principle, in some circumstances, even though a trial court's ruling is based on improper reasoning, the ruling will be upheld if there is any theory or principle of law in the record which would support the ruling.

This longstanding principle of appellate law, sometimes referred to as the 'tipsy coachman' doctrine, allows an appellate court to affirm a trial court that reaches the right result but for the wrong reasons so long as there is any basis which would support the judgment in the record.
story:
In a bustling city, Sarah had just purchased her dream vintage car, a classic convertible that she had long coveted. Eager to take it out for a spin, she decided to drive to the nearest park.

On her way, Sarah encountered a busy intersection where traffic lights suddenly malfunctioned, causing chaos as cars tried to navigate through. Amidst the confusion, Sarah did her best to safely maneuver her new car through the intersection. However, another driver failed to yield and the two vehicles collided.

The case went to trial, and the judge ruled in favor of Sarah, holding the other driver responsible for the accident. However, the judge's reasoning seemed off, citing an incorrect law that did not apply to the situation.

Upon appeal, the higher court acknowledged the trial judge's flawed reasoning but used the 'Tipsy Coachman' doctrine to uphold the ruling in Sarah's favor. Despite the incorrect legal basis cited by the trial judge, the higher court found another legal principle in the record that justified the outcome – the other driver's failure to yield.

In the end, justice prevailed for Sarah thanks to the 'Tipsy Coachman' doctrine, ensuring that the correct decision was upheld, even if the legal reasoning was a bit wobbly.

definition:
Tolling is a legal doctrine that allows for the pausing or delaying of the running of the period of time set forth by a statute of limitations, such that a lawsuit may potentially be filed even after the statute of limitations has run. Although grounds for tolling the statute of limitations vary by jurisdiction, common grounds include:

The plaintiff was a minor at the time a cause of action accrued.
The plaintiff has been deemed mentally incompetent.
The plaintiff has been convicted of a felony and is imprisoned.
The defendant has filed a bankruptcy case triggering a stay of other lawsuits.
The defendant is not physically within a certain jurisdiction (for example, a state or country).
The parties were engaged in good-faith negotiations to resolve a dispute without litigation when the statute of limitations expired.
Tolling may occur under a statute that specifically provides for the tolling of the statute of limitations during specified circumstances. It may also take the form of equitable tolling, where the court applies common law principles of equity to extend the time for the filing of a document.
story:
Emily, a young aspiring chef, was involved in a car accident caused by a negligent driver. She sustained serious injuries and had to undergo multiple surgeries and extensive rehabilitation. Overwhelmed by her recovery and medical bills, Emily was unable to pursue legal action against the driver within the set timeframe of the statute of limitations.

However, during the same period, Emily's health took a turn for the worse, and she was diagnosed with a mental health condition that required ongoing treatment. As a result, she was considered mentally incompetent to handle her affairs effectively, including initiating a lawsuit for her injuries.

Emily's family, understanding the situation, sought legal advice and discovered the concept of tolling. They learned that in cases where the plaintiff has been deemed mentally incompetent, the statute of limitations may be paused or delayed to allow for the filing of a lawsuit at a later date.

With this newfound information, Emily's family successfully applied for tolling of the statute of limitations due to her mental health condition. This allowed them the necessary time to focus on Emily's recovery while ensuring she had the opportunity to seek justice for the harm caused by the accident.

definition:
The totality principle is a common law principle which applies when a court imposes multiple sentences of imprisonment. The principle was first formulated by David Thomas in his 1970 study of the sentencing decisions of the Court of Appeal of England and Wales:

The effect of the totality principle is to require a sentencer who has passed a series of sentences, each properly calculated in relation to the offence for which it is imposed and each properly made consecutive in accordance with the principles governing consecutive sentences, to review the aggregate sentence and consider whether the aggregate is 'just and appropriate'. The principle has been stated many times in various forms: 'when a number of offences are being dealt with and specific punishments in respect of them are being totted up to make a total, it is always necessary for the court to take a last look at the total just to see whether it looks wrong'; 'when ... cases of multiplicity of offences come before the court, the court must not content itself by doing the arithmetic and passing the sentence which the arithmetic produces. It must look at the totality of the criminal behaviour and ask itself what is the appropriate sentence for all the offences.'
story:
In a small town, Sarah found herself in a tough situation. She was caught shoplifting from three different stores on the same day. The judge, taking each offense into account, sentenced her to 60 days in jail for each theft, to be served consecutively.

As Sarah sat in her cell, she couldn't shake the feeling that her punishment seemed overly harsh. Reflecting on her actions, she realized the gravity of what she had done and vowed to turn her life around.

During her appeal hearing, Sarah's attorney argued for the application of the totality principle. He emphasized that while each individual theft deserved punishment, when looking at the total aggregate of her crimes, the sentence seemed disproportionate to the overall criminal behavior.

The judge, considering the totality of the circumstances, decided to reduce Sarah's total sentence to 90 days in jail. He acknowledged that Sarah had made a mistake but recognized her genuine remorse and commitment to change.

As Sarah walked out of the courtroom, she realized the importance of the totality principle in ensuring that justice is fair and proportionate, taking into account the overall context of an individual's actions.

definition:
Transnational child protection refers to the protection of children from violence, exploitation, abuse and neglect in an international setting. When a non-national child comes into contact with public authorities and service providers, a series of checks, assessments and immediate measures sets in to identify the child and to assess her or his situation. Article 19 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child provides for the protection of children in and out of the home, including in their country of origin, residence or a third country. Article 2 of the Convention provides for the right to non-discrimination, meaning children have the right to protection regardless of the national origin or status of the child or his or her parents or legal guardians.
A child may become party to a transnational child protection case because of a need for protection, including: due to international adoption, being born to parents with different or multiple nationalities, being born in a different country than either parent's nationality, and migrating or being trafficked. Being an unaccompanied or separated minor comes with particular challenges.
story:
In a bustling city, little Maya found herself lost in a sea of unfamiliar faces. She had traveled from a distant country with her parents, who were seeking better opportunities for their family. However, in the chaos of the crowded streets, Maya became separated from them.

A kind passerby noticed Maya's distress and alerted the authorities. As a non-national child in a foreign land, Maya's situation triggered the protocols of transnational child protection. The authorities swiftly intervened, ensuring Maya's safety and well-being. They provided her with temporary shelter, food, and clothing while they tried to locate her parents.

As the hours turned into days, it became clear that Maya's parents were nowhere to be found. The authorities began the process of determining Maya's legal status and assessing her needs. Despite the language barrier, dedicated social workers and translators worked tirelessly to provide Maya with the care and support she required.

Through the principles of non-discrimination and the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, Maya was given the same level of protection as any child in need, regardless of her nationality or immigration status. In the end, Maya's story had a happy ending as a loving family in the city stepped forward to provide her with a new home and a fresh start in her unfamiliar surroundings.

definition: In international law, a treaty body (or treaty-based body) is an internationally established body of independent experts that monitor how States party to a particular international legal instrument are implementing their obligations under it.
story:
In a small coastal town nestled along the shores of the Atlantic Ocean, a group of fishermen have been facing challenges with dwindling fish populations for years. Frustrated by the declining resources that sustained their livelihoods, they decided to take action.

Gathering together, the fishermen drafted a petition detailing their concerns and sent it off to an international organization known as the Treaty body for the Protection of Marine Resources. This treaty body, composed of experts in marine conservation and sustainable fishing practices from various countries, was tasked with overseeing the implementation of an international agreement aimed at preserving marine biodiversity.

After receiving the fishermen's petition, the Treaty body launched an investigation to assess the state of marine resources in the town's waters. They conducted inspections, reviewed data on fishing practices, and engaged with local authorities to understand the situation comprehensively.

Following their thorough review, the Treaty body issued recommendations to the town and the national government on ways to improve the management of marine resources and ensure sustainable fishing practices. These recommendations led to the adoption of new regulations, enforcement mechanisms, and conservation initiatives, ultimately helping the fishermen and their community to protect their livelihoods and the marine environment for future generations.

Through the intervention of the Treaty body, the fishermen learned firsthand the importance of international cooperation and oversight in upholding commitments to preserve our shared natural resources.

definition:
An unaccompanied minor (sometimes "unaccompanied child" or "separated child") is a child without the presence of a legal guardian.
The UN Committee on the Rights of the Child defines unaccompanied minors and unaccompanied children as those "who have been separated from both parents and other relatives and are not being cared for by an adult who, by law or custom, is responsible for doing so." The Committee defines separated children as those "who have been separated from both parents, or from their previous legal or customary primary care-giver, but not necessarily from other relatives. These may, therefore, include children accompanied by other adult family members."
The number of unaccompanied minors increased drastically from 16,067 to 68,541 during 2011 to 2014.
story:
In a bustling city, Lily, a 10-year-old girl from a war-torn country, found herself alone in a crowded train station. Her heart raced as she clutched a crumpled note with her mother's name on it. But her mother was nowhere to be seen. Lost and frightened, Lily became an unaccompanied minor in a foreign land.

As tears welled up in her eyes, a kindhearted security guard approached her. Understanding the situation, he gently took Lily's hand and led her to the station office. There, they contacted the authorities to help locate her family. 

Days passed, and Lily stayed in a temporary shelter for unaccompanied minors. She missed her mother dearly, but found comfort in the caring staff who ensured she had a warm bed and meals. They explained to Lily that she was considered an unaccompanied minor because she was separated from her mother without any adult family member to care for her.

Through the support of social workers and lawyers specializing in children's rights, Lily's case was diligently handled. Finally, after a month, Lily was joyfully reunited with her mother, who had been searching desperately for her.

The experience opened Lily's eyes to the complexities of being an unaccompanied minor, but also highlighted the importance of protection and care for children in vulnerable situations.

definition: Unconscionability (sometimes known as unconscionable dealing/conduct in Australia) is a doctrine in contract law that describes terms that are so extremely unjust, or overwhelmingly one-sided in favor of the party who has the superior bargaining power, that they are contrary to good conscience.  Typically, an unconscionable contract is held to be unenforceable because no reasonable or informed person would otherwise agree to it. The perpetrator of the conduct is not allowed to benefit, because the consideration offered is lacking, or is so obviously inadequate, that to enforce the contract would be unfair to the party seeking to escape the contract.
story:
Once upon a time, Sarah, a struggling artist, entered into a contract with a wealthy art gallery owner, Mr. Greystone. Excited to showcase her work, Sarah eagerly signed the agreement without fully understanding its terms. Little did she know that the contract was unconscionable.

In the contract, Mr. Greystone had included a clause that required Sarah to give up all rights to her artwork in perpetuity. This meant that not only would he own every piece she created, but he could also reproduce and sell them without giving her any royalties or credit.

As Sarah's art gained popularity, she realized the one-sided nature of the contract and sought legal advice. Her lawyer explained that the terms were unconscionable as they heavily favored Mr. Greystone and deprived Sarah of fair compensation for her hard work and talent.

Sarah decided to challenge the contract in court, arguing that no reasonable artist would agree to such oppressive terms. The judge agreed and ruled the contract unenforceable due to its unconscionability. Sarah was relieved to regain control of her artwork and learned a valuable lesson about the importance of reviewing contracts thoroughly before signing.

This story of Sarah and Mr. Greystone serves as a cautionary tale about the consequences of entering into agreements that are unconscionable and highlights the legal protection available to prevent exploitation in contractual relationships.

definition:
Unconscionability in English law is a field of contract law and the law of trusts, which precludes the enforcement of voluntary (or consensual) obligations unfairly exploiting the unequal power of the consenting parties. "Inequality of bargaining power" is another term used to express essentially the same idea for the same area of law, which can in turn be further broken down into cases on duress, undue influence and exploitation of weakness. In these cases, where someone's consent to a bargain was only procured through duress, out of undue influence or under severe external pressure that another person exploited, courts have felt it was unconscionable (i.e., contrary to good conscience) to enforce agreements. Any transfers of goods or money may be claimed back in restitution on the basis of unjust enrichment subject to certain defences.
Considerable controversy is still present over whether "iniquitous pressure" must actually be exercised by a defendant in order for a voluntary obligation to be voidable. While it seems clear that in cases of undue influence the pressure need not come from the person who may lose the contract, it is open to debate whether circumstances exist where an obligation should be voidable simply because the person was pressured by circumstances wholly outside a defendant's control.
One of the most prominent cases in this area is Lloyds Bank Ltd v Bundy, where Lord Denning MR advocated that there be a general principle to govern this entire area. He called the concept "inequality of bargaining power", while the American case espousing an equivalent doctrine, Williams v. Walker-Thomas Furniture Co. (1965), termed the issue one of "unconscionability". Note that even though it is accepted that an "inequality of bargaining power" is relevant to the doctrine of undue influence, Lord Denning's broader dictum on a general equitable principle of an "inequality of bargaining power" was later rejected by the House of Lords in the 1985 case National Westminster Bank plc v Morgan.
story:
Once upon a time in a small town, Sarah, a struggling single mother, found herself in desperate need of a loan to cover her daughter's medical expenses. Desperate and vulnerable, she approached a local moneylender, Mr. Smith, for help. Mr. Smith saw Sarah's predicament and offered her a loan at an exorbitant interest rate, knowing she had no other options.

Sarah, feeling trapped and with no one else to turn to, reluctantly accepted the loan under the unreasonable terms set by Mr. Smith. Over time, she found herself drowning in debt as the interest continued to pile up, making it impossible for her to repay the loan.

As Sarah sought legal advice, it became clear that the agreement she entered into with Mr. Smith was unconscionable. The unequal bargaining power between them, with Sarah's vulnerability and Mr. Smith's exploitation of her desperate situation, rendered the contract unfair and unjust.

With the help of her lawyer, Sarah was able to challenge the agreement in court, arguing that it was voidable due to unconscionability. The court, recognizing the imbalance of power and the exploitation of Sarah's weakness, ruled in her favor. Sarah was relieved of the unfair burden imposed on her by Mr. Smith's exploitative tactics, illustrating the legal concept of unconscionability in a relatable and poignant manner.

definition:
An undue hardship is an American and Canadian legal term referring to special or specified circumstances that partially or fully exempt a person or organization from performance of a legal obligation so as to avoid an unreasonable or disproportionate burden or obstacle.
For example, employers are required to provide a reasonable accommodation to qualified individuals with disabilities, but when an accommodation becomes too taxing on the organization it is classified as an undue hardship and is no longer required.  
These hardships include the nature and cost of the accommodation in relation to the size, resources, nature, and structure of the employer's operation. In the religious exemption context, undue burden is separately defined as anything "more than de minimus", as opposed to onerous or costly burdens.
story:
Emma was a dedicated manager at a busy marketing firm, known for her inclusive leadership style. When one of her top performers, Sarah, requested an extended leave for religious observance, Emma was supportive and began exploring options to accommodate Sarah's needs.

As the firm's operations relied heavily on Sarah's expertise, finding a way to cover her responsibilities during her absence proved challenging. Emma proposed temporary reassignments and adjustments to the workflow, but they seemed insufficient to meet the demands without overburdening the team. 

The HR department conducted an analysis and determined that hiring temporary staff to fill Sarah's role would strain the company's budget significantly. Despite their best efforts, the available accommodations were deemed to impose an unreasonable burden on the organization, affecting its productivity and financial stability.

Reluctantly, Emma had to inform Sarah that while they valued her contribution and respected her religious practices, providing the requested accommodation would result in undue hardship for the firm. Together, they explored alternative solutions and eventually found a compromise that balanced Sarah's needs with the company's operational limitations.

definition:
Undue influence (UI) is a psychological process by which a person's free will and judgement is supplanted by that of another. It is a legal term and the strict definition varies by jurisdiction. Generally speaking, it is a means by which a person gains control over their victims' decision making through manipulation tactics and unfair pressure, typically for financial gain. Historically, UI has been poorly understood, even in some legal circles.
Undue influence is typically perpetrated by a person who is trusted by the victim and is dependent on them for emotional and physical needs. Caregivers are often found to have unduly influenced their patients, however, anyone in a position of trust and authority over the victim (e.g. fiduciary) may be guilty. This includes the victims' attorney, accountant, nursing home attendant, or even children. UI is a process, not a single event. A manipulator may spend weeks, months, or even years before successfully unduly-influencing their victim. Anyone is susceptible to UI, but the elderly are particularly vulnerable. Perpetrators of UI operate in shadow, enacting their manipulation behind closed doors where there are no witnesses. A person being unduly influenced may become withdrawn, depressive and passive. Physical signs of abuse may include unexplained bruising, scratches, and/or broken bones. Other signs may include missing or broken dentures, prescription eyeglasses, hearing aids or other assistive devices. 
A distinction is made between the nature of capacity and undue influence. In assessing capacity, the practitioner evaluates an individual's ability to competently perform tasks (e.g., execute a will or give medical consent). These assessments give insight to the functioning of the cognitive capabilities at that moment in time. Conversely, screening for undue influence is focused on the process of events which occur over an extended period. To determine whether another person is leveraging unfair tactics on the victim, an assessment specific to undue influence is required. 
Undue influence occurs in various circumstances including, but not limited to domestic violence, hostage situations, cults, prisoners of war, and dictatorships. The common theme among these situations is the aspect of psychological manipulation. Traumatic bonding may occur between the victim and influencer, as a result, the victim may even defend the perpetrator. The effectiveness of cult tactics (e.g. love bombing) on young and healthy individuals illustrates that anyone, regardless of mental status, is a potential victim of UI under certain circumstances.
Elderly Americans are living longer, and with this increased life expectancy, the prevalence of cognitive disorders associated with advanced age has also increased. A significant concentration of wealth is controlled by this aging demographic making them a potential target for exploitation.  Modern families are becoming more complex and dispersed. Given these factors, the number of will contests involving undue influence is expected to increase.
story:
Sarah, a sweet and trusting elderly widow, had always been close to her only son, John. However, as Sarah's health began to decline, John started taking over more and more of her affairs, from managing her finances to making decisions about her healthcare.

At first, Sarah felt grateful to have her son's help, but she soon began to notice a change in his behavior. John became controlling and manipulative, often using guilt and emotional pressure to get his way. He would isolate Sarah from her friends and other family members, insisting that he knew what was best for her.

Over time, Sarah's once vibrant personality faded away, replaced by a sense of dependence and fear of going against her son's wishes. She began to sign legal documents that she didn't fully understand, giving John even more control over her life and assets.

It wasn't until a concerned neighbor noticed Sarah's increasingly reclusive behavior and reached out for help that the truth came to light. Through careful investigation, it was revealed that John had been unduly influencing his mother for his own financial gain, taking advantage of her vulnerability and diminishing capacity.

This heartbreaking story of undue influence serves as a cautionary tale about the importance of recognizing the signs of manipulation and standing up against those who seek to exploit others for their own benefit.

definition:
Undue influence in English law is a field of contract law and property law whereby a transaction may be set aside if it was procured by the influence exerted by one person on another, such that the transaction "ought not fairly to be as treated the expression of [that] person's free will".
Historically, the doctrine had predominantly been invoked where the person who is exercising undue influence over another person either enters into a contract with the affected person or receives a gift from them. However, much of the recent case law relates to three party cases, where one person (often a husband) exerts undue influence on a second person (the wife) to enter into a transaction (providing a guarantee or security for the husband's debts) with a third party (often a bank).  The doctrine originally developed because of perceived limitations in the law relating to duress. Although the modern law is different, previously in order to set aside a contract for duress it was necessary to show a threat of violence to the person (this is now no longer the case), and the doctrine developed in response to more subtle forms of coercion.  Accordingly, many earlier cases which refer to undue influence are capable of being reconsidered as actually relating to duress or unconscionable bargains in the modern sense.
The leading authority on undue influence is now the decision of the House of Lords in Royal Bank of Scotland v Etridge (No 2), but much of the earlier case law continues to be relevant. There has been no real statutory intervention in this area of the law. Despite the wide array of cases considering the doctrine, there remains some disagreement as to the precise ambit of the doctrine.
story:
Sarah, a successful businesswoman, was happily married to Mark, a charming but financially irresponsible husband. Mark was constantly in debt due to his reckless spending habits and risky investments. Sarah had always managed the finances in their household to ensure stability.

One day, Mark approached Sarah with a proposal to invest in a risky business venture that he believed would bring in substantial profits. Despite her reservations, Mark was insistent and began to exert subtle pressure on Sarah, highlighting the potential rewards and downplaying the risks. Feeling torn between supporting her husband and protecting their financial security, Sarah reluctantly agreed to invest a significant sum of money in the venture.

As the business venture failed and their finances spiraled into chaos, Sarah realized that she had been unduly influenced by Mark's persuasive tactics. She sought legal advice and learned about the concept of undue influence in English law. With the help of her lawyer, Sarah was able to set aside the transaction, arguing that it was procured by the undue influence exerted by Mark.

Through Sarah's story, we see how the legal concept of undue influence can come into play in situations where one party exerts pressure or influence over another, leading to a transaction that is not truly the expression of free will.

definition:
Uninsured employer in the United States is a term to identify an employer of workers under circumstances where there is no form of insurance in place to provide certain benefits to those workers.  More specifically, it is a term used in workers’ compensation law to identify an employer who does not have some form of worker's compensation insurance or self-insurance coverage in effect at the time of, or during the time of, a claimed injury.
All States require that employers provide injury benefits coverage to their employees. These benefits are called workers’ compensation insurance coverage.  This kind of coverage is to be distinguished from liability coverage, which covers the premises and the owner/occupier of the space from claims made by non-employees for injuries on the premises. It is also to be distinguished from health insurance, which covers only medical bills for non-work incurred conditions.
Protection can be accomplished through a traditional insurance policy for workers’ compensation coverage. Coverage can also be accomplished by way of compliance with various State self-insurance laws (usually reserved for larger employers) requiring substantial bonding and self-funding.  For example, public agencies are usually permissibly self-insured.
When the employer has no specific insurance, or arrangement for the provision of workers’ compensation benefits to injured employees, the employer is then referred to as an uninsured employer.
story:
Sarah worked at a small construction company that was struggling to make ends meet. The owner, John, always assured his employees that he would take care of them in case of any injuries on the job. However, John never actually had workers’ compensation insurance in place for his employees.

One day, while working on a construction site, Sarah fell from a ladder and severely injured her back. She was rushed to the hospital and faced extensive medical bills and a long recovery ahead. When she asked John about workers’ compensation benefits to help cover her medical expenses and lost wages, he confessed that he did not have any insurance coverage for such situations.

Feeling betrayed and helpless, Sarah sought legal advice and learned that John, as an uninsured employer, was in violation of the law by failing to provide workers’ compensation insurance. She had the right to pursue a legal claim against him for her injuries and losses, seeking compensation through other means.

Through Sarah's story, it became clear that when an employer fails to provide workers’ compensation benefits due to lack of insurance coverage, they are considered an uninsured employer, leaving their employees vulnerable in times of need.

doctrine: United States v. American Bell Telephone Co.
definition: United States v. Bell Telephone Co., 167 U.S. 224 (1897), is an 1897 decision of the United States Supreme Court that held that the United States lacked standing to challenge the validity of its issued patents “on the mere ground of error of judgment” in issuing them. The United States had standing to seek to invalidate patents, however, on grounds of fraudulent procurement and also as a defense to a charge of patent infringement. The decision operated for many decades as a bar to government efforts to seek invalidation of patents that it considered spurious until the Supreme Court limited Bell Telephone, first to a limited extent in United States v. United States Gypsum Co., and then more broadly in United States v. Glaxo Group Ltd.
story:
Once upon a time, in a bustling town, there was a brilliant inventor named Sarah who had created a groundbreaking new device that could revolutionize communication. Excited about her invention, she promptly filed for a patent with the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

However, a rival inventor named Max became envious of Sarah's success and decided to challenge the validity of her patent. He claimed that Sarah's patent was issued in error and that her invention was not truly novel.

The case went to court, mirroring the legal concept of United States v. American Bell Telephone Co. The judge ruled that, just like in the Bell Telephone case, the United States could not challenge Sarah's patent solely based on an error in judgment. However, the court did allow for the patent to be invalidated if it was proven that Sarah had obtained it fraudulently.

In the end, it was discovered that Max had actually attempted to bribe a patent examiner to delay Sarah's patent approval, leading to the reversal of his challenge. Sarah's patent stood strong, and she continued to be celebrated for her innovative communication device.

Through this story, we see how the legal concept from United States v. American Bell Telephone Co. plays out in a modern, relatable setting, emphasizing the importance of valid patent procedures and protections.

doctrine: United States v. Glaxo Group Ltd.
definition: United States v. Glaxo Group Ltd., 410 U.S. 52 (1973), is a 1973 decision of the United States Supreme Court in which the Court held that (1) when a patent is directly involved in an antitrust violation, the Government may challenge the validity of the patent; and (2) ordinarily, in patent-antitrust cases, "[m]andatory selling on specified terms and compulsory patent licensing at reasonable charges are recognized antitrust remedies."
story:
In the bustling world of pharmaceuticals, two giants, PharmaCo and BioCure, were neck and neck in the race to develop a groundbreaking new cancer treatment. PharmaCo held a patent on a key component crucial to the drug's effectiveness.

However, as the competition heated up, BioCure accused PharmaCo of anti-competitive behavior, alleging that PharmaCo was using its patent power to stifle competition and keep prices high. The United States government stepped in, taking a page from the playbook of the landmark case United States v. Glaxo Group Ltd.

During the legal battle that ensued, it was revealed that PharmaCo had indeed engaged in antitrust violations by using its patent to dominate the market unfairly. The court, referencing United States v. Glaxo Group Ltd., ruled that the government had the right to challenge the validity of PharmaCo's patent in light of its involvement in antitrust violations.

As a result, the court mandated that PharmaCo must engage in mandatory selling on specified terms and compulsory patent licensing at reasonable charges, allowing BioCure and other competitors to access the vital component needed for the cancer treatment. This decision leveled the playing field, promoting competition, and ultimately benefiting patients in need of the life-saving medication.

definition:
Universal jurisdiction is a legal principle that allows states or international organizations to prosecute individuals for serious crimes, such as genocide, war crimes, and crimes against humanity, regardless of where the crime was committed and irrespective of the accused's nationality or residence. Rooted in the belief that certain offenses are universally morally reprehensible and that they threaten the international community as a whole, universal jurisdiction holds that such acts are beyond the scope of any single nation's laws. Instead, these crimes are considered to violate norms owed to the global community (erga omnes) and fundamental principles of international law (jus cogens), making them prosecutable in any court that invokes this principle.
While universal jurisdiction has been championed by organizations such as Amnesty International for ensuring that perpetrators of grave crimes find no refuge, it remains controversial. Critics, like former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, argue that it undermines national sovereignty and risks turning judicial proceedings into politically motivated trials. The principle gained prominence following the Nuremberg trials after World War II, which prosecuted Nazi officials for crimes against humanity, even when such acts were legal under German law at the time. Since then, it has been invoked in various international tribunals and national courts to address impunity for crimes committed in conflict zones or under repressive regimes.
Notably, universal jurisdiction has been applied in cases like Israel’s prosecution of Adolf Eichmann in 1961, the trials of Rwandan genocide perpetrators, and the prosecution of former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet. The establishment of the International Criminal Court (ICC) further strengthened this concept, though its use remains contentious, often constrained by political considerations and the practical challenges of enforcing extraterritorial justice.
story:
In a small town nestled in the mountains, Maria, a young activist, stumbled upon a chilling discovery. Hidden deep within a remote cabin, she found evidence of a heinous massacre committed by a notorious warlord known for his brutal reign of terror in a distant country. Shocked and determined to seek justice, Maria contacted a global human rights organization, who revealed the legal principle of universal jurisdiction.

Driven by a sense of moral duty, Maria embarked on a relentless pursuit of justice, gathering testimonies and evidence to build a case against the warlord. With the support of international legal experts, she filed charges in a court that recognized universal jurisdiction, regardless of the warlord's nationality or where the crimes were committed.

As the trial unfolded, the world watched in awe as the once untouchable warlord faced accountability for his monstrous deeds. The courtroom became a symbol of hope, where the power of universal jurisdiction transcended borders and brought justice to the victims, offering a glimpse of closure and healing to a shattered community.

Through Maria's courageous journey, the town learned firsthand the significance of universal jurisdiction – a beacon of justice that defies tyranny and upholds the collective values of humanity, reminding us all that no one is above the law when it comes to grave atrocities.

definition:
Valid when made (also sometimes valid-when-made) is a United States legal doctrine that holds that the terms of a loan, if legally valid when the loan was made, remain valid after the loan is sold or assigned to a third party. Historically, the doctrine has often been applied to loans made by national banks and then transferred to secondary lenders. Under this doctrine, debt buyers may purchase loans from national banks and collect interest at the same rate as the original lender, regardless of the usury laws of the state they operate in.
The doctrine entered common law during the 19th century and was codified in a final rule by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency in 2020.
story:
Once upon a time, there was a small business owner named Sarah who had taken out a business loan from a national bank to expand her catering company. The loan agreement stated a fixed interest rate of 5%, which Sarah diligently paid back every month.

One day, the national bank decided to sell Sarah's loan to a secondary lender to free up capital for other investments. The secondary lender, unaware of the legal concept of 'Valid when made', assumed they could charge a higher interest rate on the loan to increase their profits.

When the secondary lender tried to increase the interest rate to 10%, Sarah was understandably upset. She contacted a lawyer, who explained to her that under the doctrine of 'Valid when made', the terms of the loan, including the 5% interest rate, remained valid even after the loan was sold.

Armed with this knowledge, Sarah was able to challenge the secondary lender's attempt to raise her interest rate unlawfully. The secondary lender had to honor the original terms of the loan, providing Sarah with peace of mind and ensuring she could continue growing her business without facing unjust financial burdens.

In the end, Sarah learned that the legal concept of 'Valid when made' protected borrowers like her from unfair changes to their loan terms when loans are transferred to third parties.

definition: Vicarious liability is a form of a  strict, secondary liability that arises under the common law doctrine of agency, respondeat superior, the responsibility of the superior for the acts of their subordinate or, in a broader sense, the responsibility of any third party that had the "right, ability, or duty to control" the activities of a violator. It can be distinguished from contributory liability, another form of secondary liability, which is rooted in the tort theory of enterprise liability because, unlike contributory infringement, knowledge is not an element of vicarious liability. The law has developed the view that some relationships by their nature require the person who engages others to accept responsibility for the wrongdoing of those others. The most important such relationship for practical purposes is that of employer and employee.
story:
In a bustling city, Sarah owned a popular bakery known for its delicious pastries and friendly service. She hired Alex as her head baker, entrusting him with managing the kitchen and overseeing the other bakers.

One busy morning, a customer named Lily walked into the bakery and slipped on a wet floor, injuring herself. It was later revealed that the floor had been wet because Alex neglected to clean up a spilled container of milk promptly. Lily decided to seek compensation for her injuries through a legal case.

In court, Sarah was shocked to learn that she could be held responsible for Lily's injuries through the legal concept of vicarious liability. Despite not directly causing the accident, Sarah was considered liable because Alex, as her employee, was acting within the scope of his employment when the incident occurred.

The judge explained that as an employer, Sarah had a duty to ensure her employees acted responsibly and safely in the workplace. By failing to properly supervise Alex and ensure a safe environment for customers, Sarah could be held vicariously liable for the consequences of Alex's negligence.

This case exemplified how the law holds employers accountable for the actions of their employees when performed within the scope of their employment, emphasizing the importance of proper supervision and responsibility in the workplace.

definition:
A wrong or wrength (from Old English wrang – 'crooked') is an act that is illegal or immoral. Legal wrongs are usually quite clearly defined in the law of a state or jurisdiction. They can be divided into civil wrongs and crimes (or criminal offenses) in common law countries, while civil law countries tend to have some additional categories, such as contraventions.
Moral wrong is an underlying concept for legal wrong. Some moral wrongs are punishable by law, for example, rape or murder. Other moral wrongs have nothing to do with law but are related to unethical behaviours. On the other hand, some legal wrongs, such as many types of parking offences, could hardly be classified as moral wrongs.
story:
In a bustling city neighborhood, Sarah ran a popular bakery known for its delicious pastries. One day, a new competitor, Jack's Pastries, opened up just down the street. Business started dwindling for Sarah as customers flocked to the shiny new bakery.

Determined to uncover the reason behind her declining sales, Sarah discovered that Jack was using her secret recipe for her signature strawberry shortcake. Shocked and angered by this violation of intellectual property rights, Sarah sought legal advice. It was clear that Jack's actions constituted a violation of the law by infringing on Sarah's copyrighted recipe without permission.

Sarah decided to take legal action against Jack for his wrongdoing. After a lengthy legal battle, the court ruled in Sarah's favor, ordering Jack to pay damages for his violation of the law. Jack's Pastries was forced to shut down, serving as a cautionary tale for businesses about the consequences of committing legal wrongs.

The story of Sarah and Jack's Pastries serves as a reminder that violations of the law, whether through intellectual property theft or other means, can have serious repercussions and jeopardize the livelihoods of those affected.

definition:
Volenti non fit iniuria (or injuria) (Latin: "to a willing person, injury is not done") is a Roman legal maxim and common law doctrine which states that if someone willingly places themselves in a position where harm might result, knowing that some degree of harm might result, they are not able to bring a claim against the other party in tort or delict. Volenti applies only to the risk which a reasonable person would consider them as having assumed by their actions; thus a boxer consents to being hit, and to the injuries that might be expected from being hit, but does not consent to (for example) his opponent striking him with an iron bar, or punching him outside the usual terms of boxing.  Volenti is also known as a "voluntary assumption of risk".
Volenti is sometimes described as the plaintiff "consenting to run a risk". In this context, volenti can be distinguished from legal consent in that the latter can prevent some torts arising in the first place. For example, consent to a medical procedure prevents the procedure from being a trespass to the person, or consenting to a person visiting one's land prevents them from being a trespasser.
story:
Kim, an adventure-seeking thrill-seeker, decided to try bungee jumping for the first time. As she stood on the platform, straps securely fastened, she felt a rush of excitement and fear. The instructor explained the safety measures and asked if she was ready. With a nervous smile, Kim nodded, indicating her consent to jump.

As she plunged towards the ground below, the bungee cord rebounded, propelling her back up into the air. However, halfway through the jump, Kim felt a sudden jolt as the cord snapped. She ended up with a sprained ankle upon landing.

Frustrated and in pain, Kim considered taking legal action against the bungee jumping company. However, upon consulting a lawyer, she learned about the legal concept of volenti non fit injuria. Because Kim voluntarily assumed the inherent risks associated with bungee jumping, including the potential for equipment failure, she could not hold the company liable for her injury.

Although disappointed with the outcome, Kim realized that by willingly participating in such a risky activity, she accepted the possibility of harm. Volenti non fit injuria served as a reminder that personal responsibility and informed consent are crucial factors in determining legal liability in such cases.

definition:
The Wagoner Doctrine is an American United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit legal principle applying the longstanding common law in pari delicto (roughly translated "in equal fault") rule in the bankruptcy setting.
Though controversial due to its willingness to bar recovery in what is typically considered an equitable proceeding (i.e., bankruptcy) and thus not well accepted in other circuits, Wagoner holds that "a claim against a third party for defrauding a corporation with the cooperation of corporate management accrues to the creditors, and not to the guilty corporation."
See in pari delicto for more information.
story:
Once upon a time, there was a family-owned manufacturing company, Wilson Industries, run by the Wilson brothers, Mike and Steve. Unbeknownst to the employees and creditors, the brothers engaged in a deceptive scheme with a supplier, Smith Co., to inflate their profits through overbilling.

When Wilson Industries eventually went bankrupt, the creditors were left empty-handed. Frustrated and seeking justice, the creditors sued Smith Co. for their part in the fraud. However, under the Wagoner Doctrine, the court ruled that since the Wilson brothers were the ones who orchestrated the fraud, the company itself was considered at fault. As a result, any claim against Smith Co. for defrauding Wilson Industries belonged to the creditors and not the guilty corporation.

Despite the creditors' disappointment at not being able to hold Smith Co. directly accountable, the Wagoner Doctrine illustrated the principle of in pari delicto – in equal fault – where the actions of the wrongdoers within the corporation were attributed to the company as a whole. It was a tough lesson in the legal intricacies of corporate fraud and responsibility.

definition: Wahkohtowin is a Cree word which denotes the interconnected nature of relationships, communities, and natural systems. Its literal meaning is "kinship", but it is often used to refer to Cree law, or Cree codes of conduct.
story:
In a small Cree community nestled amidst the forest, there lived a young woman named Aiyana who cherished her deep connection to the land, animals, and her neighbors. One cold winter day, as she was venturing through the snow-covered woods, Aiyana stumbled upon a wounded wolf pup. Despite the piercing winds and freezing temperatures, she carefully carried the pup back to her home.

Word quickly spread through the community about Aiyana's selfless act, and soon, neighbors arrived bearing gifts of warm blankets, healing herbs, and food to care for the injured pup. Each person played a role in nurturing the young wolf back to health, embodying the code of Wahkohtowin - the understanding that all beings are interconnected and responsible for each other's well-being.

As the days passed, the wolf pup thrived under the collective care and attention of the community. Aiyana, guided by the principles of Wahkohtowin, formed a lasting bond with the wolf and learned valuable lessons about the importance of reciprocity and harmony within the interconnected web of life. Through her actions, she not only saved a life but also strengthened the ties that bound her community together, echoing the wisdom of their Cree ancestors and the inherent laws of kinship.

definition:
Warranty tolling refers to a legal requirement, in some jurisdictions, that the timeframe provided in a product warranty shall be tolled (paused) to protect the consumer from unfairly being deprived of its protections.
For example, under California Civil Code Sections 1795.6 and 1795.7, tolling occurs when the buyer delivers goods to be repaired or provides notice of the problem, and continues so long as the buyer has not yet received the repaired goods or notice that the repairs are complete.
story:
Mary purchased a brand-new laptop from a local electronics store, excited to use it for her work and personal projects. The laptop came with a one-year warranty covering any manufacturing defects or malfunctions.

A few months into using the laptop, Mary noticed that it was shutting down unexpectedly and displaying strange error messages. Concerned about the issue, she promptly contacted the manufacturer and shipped the laptop to their repair center as instructed.

As weeks passed without any updates or repaired laptop returned to her, Mary started to worry. According to the warranty terms, the repair should have been completed within a reasonable timeframe. However, the manufacturer seemed to be taking longer than expected.

Fortunately, the legal concept of warranty tolling came into play. In Mary's jurisdiction, the warranty timeframe was tolled from the moment she sent in her laptop for repairs until the moment she received it back in working condition. This protection ensured that Mary wouldn't unfairly lose out on the warranty coverage due to delays on the manufacturer's end.

After a few more weeks, Mary finally received her repaired laptop, grateful for the legal safeguard that allowed her to assert her warranty rights despite the delay.

definition:
Workers' compensation or workers' comp is a form of insurance providing wage replacement and medical benefits to employees injured in the course of employment in exchange for mandatory relinquishment of the employee's right to sue his or her employer for the tort of negligence.
The trade-off between assured, limited coverage and lack of recourse outside the worker compensation system is known as "the compensation bargain.” One of the problems that the compensation bargain solved is the problem of employers becoming insolvent as a result of high damage awards. The system of collective liability was created to prevent that and thus to ensure security of compensation to the workers.
While plans differ among jurisdictions, provision can be made for weekly payments in place of wages (functioning in this case as a form of disability insurance), compensation for economic loss (past and future), reimbursement or payment of medical and like expenses (functioning in this case as a form of health insurance), and benefits payable to the dependents of workers killed during employment.
General damage for pain and suffering and punitive damages for employer negligence are generally not available in workers' compensation plans, and negligence is generally not an issue in the case.
story:
Sarah worked at a busy construction site, where the sound of hammering and drilling was constant. One day, while carrying heavy equipment, she slipped on some loose gravel and fell, injuring her back.

Unable to work due to her injury, Sarah was worried about how she would make ends meet. However, her employer had workers' compensation insurance in place. This meant that Sarah was entitled to receive wage replacement and medical benefits while she recovered, without having to sue her employer for negligence.

As Sarah underwent treatment for her back injury, she didn't have to worry about paying for medical expenses or losing her income. The workers' compensation system provided her with the necessary support during this challenging time.

Meanwhile, Sarah's employer was also relieved that they had workers' compensation insurance. It protected them from potential lawsuits and financial ruin resulting from high damage awards. The system of collective liability ensured that injured workers like Sarah received the compensation they deserved, while also providing security for the employer.

Thanks to workers' compensation employer defense, Sarah could focus on her recovery without the added stress of legal battles or financial instability. It was a true example of the compensation bargain at work.

definition:
A wrong or wrength (from Old English wrang – 'crooked') is an act that is illegal or immoral. Legal wrongs are usually quite clearly defined in the law of a state or jurisdiction. They can be divided into civil wrongs and crimes (or criminal offenses) in common law countries, while civil law countries tend to have some additional categories, such as contraventions.
Moral wrong is an underlying concept for legal wrong. Some moral wrongs are punishable by law, for example, rape or murder. Other moral wrongs have nothing to do with law but are related to unethical behaviours. On the other hand, some legal wrongs, such as many types of parking offences, could hardly be classified as moral wrongs.
story:
In a small town named Willow Creek, a popular local bakery, Sweet Delights, had been thriving for years under the ownership of Mrs. Thompson, a kind-hearted elderly woman loved by all in the community. One day, a new employee named Sarah joined the bakery and quickly won over Mrs. Thompson with her charm and work ethic.

However, as weeks passed, Sarah started noticing some discrepancies in the bakery's financial records. Digging deeper, she uncovered evidence that Mrs. Thompson had been siphoning off profits for personal use, a clear case of embezzlement. Shocked and torn between loyalty to her employer and doing the right thing, Sarah decided to report the wrongdoing to the authorities.

The legal ramifications were swift, and Mrs. Thompson was charged with embezzlement, facing serious consequences for her actions. While the town was in disbelief that someone they trusted could commit such a crime, the law made no exceptions for wrongdoing, no matter how beloved the perpetrator was.

The story of Sweet Delights served as a stark reminder that legal wrongs can happen even in the most unexpected of places, emphasizing the importance of accountability and justice in society.
